urn:contentItem:4PB8-S2S0-TXW3-407S-00000-00New York Stock Exchange Update; Word From The Floor; Hays Wire; 5 for 5, CNNfn2004-09-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:25ZLexisNexisNew York Stock Exchange Update; Word From The Floor; Hays Wire; 5 for 5, CNNfnABSTRACT

A medication used to relieve pain for millions of people is now a source of pain for the company that makes it. Merck [Company: Merck & Co. Inc.; Ticker: MRK ; URL: http://www.merck.com/] is pulling its arthritis drug Vioxx effective immediately. And investors are pulling out of Merck. That stock is down 27 percent. That`s roughly $27 billion of lost market cap. The stock now at the lowest price in eight years.

FULL TEXT

CHRISTINE ROMANS, CNNfn ANCHOR, STREET SWEEP: I`m Christine Romans in New York. Counting down to the closing bell on the final day of the third quarter on Wall Street. The Dow is lower. This is STREETSWEEP.

A medication used to relieve pain for millions of people is now a source of pain for the company that makes it. Merck [Company: Merck & Co. Inc.; Ticker: MRK ; URL: http://www.merck.com/] is pulling its arthritis drug Vioxx effective immediately. And investors are pulling out of Merck. That stock is down 27 percent. That`s roughly $27 billion of lost market cap. The stock now at the lowest price in eight years.

Fred Katayama was at a Merck press conference earlier this morning. He joins us now with the details. Fred?

FRED KATAYAMA, CNNfn CORRESPONDENT: Well, Christine, the more than a million arthritis patients in the U.S. now taking Vioxx will soon have to stop taking it. It`s manufacturer Merck is pulling Vioxx off the world- wide market. The company made the decision after clinical tests results showed the drug raised the risk of heart attacks and strokes.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

RAYMOND GILMARTIN, CEO, MERCK: Importantly, in the first 18 months of the study, there is no difference in the risk for heart attack or stroke in patients taking either Vioxx or placebo. Beginning after 18 months, however, the risk of a cardiovascular event did increase among those on Vioxx. Accordingly, we are voluntarily withdrawing Vioxx effective today.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

KATAYAMA: The bombshell announcement came just weeks after Merck had insisted Vioxx was safe. An FDA study had showed that patients taking high doses of Vioxx had a three-times greater chance of a heart attack than those not taking painkillers. But today the Food and Drug Administration said Merck did the right thing in reporting its findings. And it said it would closely monitor other arthritis drugs for similar side effects.

But Merck`s investors got burned. Shares of the drug company sank to their lowest levels in nearly a decade. The Vioxx withdrawal will cut into Merck`s profits this year. It`s $2.5 billion in revenues make up more than a tenth of the company`s sales. For now, patients on Vioxx can switch to other arthritis drugs like Celebrex.

Merck says it`s clinical results do not necessarily apply to other drugs in it`s class. But some analysts say Merck`s findings might make patients more cautious about taking other arthritis drugs.

ROMANS: OK. Let`s talk about the company. Let`s talk about the executives of the company. Ray Gilmartin, the CEO at that press conference this morning. Even before this happened, there had been people on the street who have been saying the performance of the company was sub par and maybe he should resign. What do you say?

KATAYAMA: Well, the reporters did ask him at the press conference if he was going to step down. He said no.

ROMANS: What are the analysts saying about how well he`s handling this crisis?

KATAYAMA: Some people say it was good that he stepped up and voluntarily pushed forward instead of waiting for the Food and Drug Administration to mandate a withdrawal. So in a sense, the positive spin on this story is that Pfizer [Company: Pfizer Inc.; Ticker: PFE; URL: http://www.pfizer.com/] took an active role in trying to -- you know, what people call a proactive role in trying to withdraw the drugs from the market before it created any harm.

But as you know, he`s been under a lot of pressure. He said he`s not going to resign.

ROMANS: This has been a heavily advertised drug. A lot of people now -- what are people supposed to do who are on the drug? And I can`t imagine how this is going to change the entire landscape for arthritis medications. And for the other companies that make these medications.

KATAYAMA: The people who are currently on the drug, they are advised to stop taking it. Right now Pfizer is working with the medical profession to try to get those drugs off the shelves and to get patients worldwide to stop taking this drug. Now there are other options for those patients. That`s the good news.

For example, they can turn to Celebrex, which is made by Pfizer. And there are other arthritis drugs on the market. And drug analysts feel that the company that will benefit the most out of this is Pfizer, because Celebrex is currently the best-selling arthritis drug on the market. Another beneficiary Chris, according to analyst in Merrill Lynch could be Schering- Plough.

ROMANS: Oh really?

KATAYAMA: And the reason is because now that Merck is really under pressure, remember, Merck has had a weak pipeline for several years.

ROMANS: Sure.

KATAYAMA: The analyst community has said Merck you have to combine with some other company the way that Pfizer bought out Warner-Lambert. We saw consolidation in the sector. Merck said, no we`re going to go it alone. Well, the Merrill analyst thinks that is going to pressure Merck to perhaps swallow another company, possibly Schering-Plough. You know, you got to fill that pipeline.

ROMANS: Absolutely.

KATAYAMA: Especially with the $2.5 billion in revenues taken out with this Vioxx drug.

ROMANS: A very big story. And I am sure we are not going to hear the last of it. All right. Thanks, Fred Katayama.

Merck`s top competitor in the arthritis medication field as Fred said, Pfizer. And it`s shares are higher today. Shares of Pfizer, which makes Celebrex up more than 1 percent.

Later in the program in our five for five segment, I`ll speak with a money manager who says Pfizer is a good pick for your portfolio over the next five years.

Merck`s loss today accounts for the entire drop in the Dow Industrials. Without it, the market would actually be up. Rhonda Schaffler live at the New York Stock Exchange. Rhonda?

RHONDA SCHAFFLER, NEW YORK STOCK EXCHANGE: Hi Christine.

Well, as you can imagine, this story really has taken stage on Wall Street. And not only is the broader market OK. Advancers are actually leading decliners by a 3/2 margin. We have a situation here where Merck is going to impact the numbers for the quarter for the Dow with this very dramatic close that we are expecting here.

Obviously, it will be difficult for any sort of recovery late in the day. NASDAQ, though, is in a lot better shape when we look at the chart. Again because remember, there is underlying strength in the market today. You are just not seeing it with the Dow because of Merck, which is dominating the action here. Merck, in fact, is the most actively traded stock at the New York Stock Exchange today. Down about 26 percent.

This will also be one of these days where this action will go in the record books. Because at this point, the trading in Merck is on tap to have one of the top 10 one-day volumes in a single stock. So this has been a very huge story here. You are looking at how some of the other drug stocks are faring. Obviously we`ve touch on Pfizer and Celebrex, which would benefit from this news from Merck.

There are other big stories too. Fannie Mae [Company: Fannie Mae ; Ticker: FNM ; URL: http://www.fanniemae.com/] for instance. This one has been a big story it seems every day. That stock is off again as the Justice Department has opened an investigation into possible accounting fraud at that company. This comes after Fannie Mae`s government regulators said last week the company may have manipulated it`s books. The agency also now will issue monthly reports regarding the company`s capital. Used to send out those reports quarterly.

Also on the earnings front, Fresh Del Monte [Company: Fresh Del Monte Produce Inc.; Ticker: FDP; URL: http://www.freshdelmonte.com/] produce cut its earnings forecast for the full year by some 50 cents a share. Del Monte now sees 2004 earnings of $2.05 to $2.15 a share. It cites lower banana prices, less profitable shares of domestic melons, go figure. And hurricane-ravaged Florida tomatoes. All those reasons sending the stock sharply lower.

And now let`s look at Gateway [Company: Gateway Inc.; Ticker: GTW; URL: http://www.gateway.com/]. A little bit of a different picture here. Gateway is unveiling a new line of desktop PCs. Customers will be able to customize their new models. Gateway also says the higher end models will have a different technology than previous systems. Earlier this month Gateway said it was going to shift its focus back to PCs. Wall Street applauding that particular piece of news. Christine?

ROMANS: All right. Rhonda Schaffler, thanks very much Rhonda, on as you said, a very big news day.

That stunning Merck decline comes on the final day of a rough quarter for a lot of stock investors. Susan Green of IDI joins me now from the New York Stock Exchange. First, you heard Rhonda say this could be one of the top 10 trading days of any individual stock in Merck. A huge move. Susan, give us a little bit of a sense how unusual it is to see a Dow component lose a quarter of its value in one day.

SUSAN GREEN, IDI: It`s actually very unusual. Something we haven`t seen in quite a while. If you take the 87 or 88 million shares out of the Dow today we`re still looking at roughly 1.35 billion shares today, which is pretty interesting. But to see a company lose almost 30 percent of its market value is extraordinary. It doesn`t happen very often.

And I think on the point of positive to positivity here, if you look at the way the stock opened, it opened and traded within a point-and-a-quarter all day long. So that 88 million shares has basically been range bound on the opening and thereafter, which is very unusual.

ROMANS: Talk to us a little bit about this coming on the last day of a quarter. I mean, you have got a lot of mutual funds that own this. "Morningstar" was telling us that Magellan . For those of you out there who own Magellan the mutual fund, or Vanguard, you are looking at you know a concentration of this particular stock in your portfolio. It`s the last day of the quarter. So it`s tough to sort of get out of a position, isn`t it?

GREEN: Well, it would be tough to get out of the position if there was no volume. That could be the reason for the stock opening at a range, staying there all day long, and trading the size that it`s trading today. They took us at a level to get it to trade. End of the quarter, people want out. New money going in. There`s a rotation going on in the stock. It needs to happen today. This is important.

They`ve managed to get it done. Then you also have to think about the fact that the Dow should probably be up on the day because of Merck being in the component, and just the way we`re seeing the market now. The money flow is directly into the market at the end of the quarter, which is actually pretty positive.

ROMANS: That`s a really good way to look at it, stripping out Merck. Merck right now is accounting for some 80, almost 90 points of Dow. The downside if you took it out, you`d actually have the Dow up a little bit.

OK. Another little factoid I wanted to give you. The Nasdaq on track for its worst quarter, even if it closed higher today, on track for its worst quarter in two years. It was a tough quarter for tech stocks. Do you feel as though there could be some momentum in the other direction for the fourth quarter?

GREEN: Well, they actually tried doing it. I mean, they got the semiconductor index, the stocks down to a level where it started trading based on the trading range. So technically, it feels as if tech stocks are actually bottomed out. But it wasn`t enough. There`s not enough momentum going into these stocks for the end of the quarter to get us going.

As we know, tech, and Nasdaq is generally tech driven, is basically forward looking. So what we need to see, management start coming out with earnings within the next two weeks is what the guidance is going to be. That`s what the focus is going to be on. That`s the only thing that`s going to get us through to the fourth quarter.

ROMANS: All right. Susan Green on the final day of a quarter. Thanks for stopping by Susan.

GREEN: Thanks Christine.

ROMANS: Coming up next on STREETSWEEP, more evidence the consumer is cutting back. At the same time jobless claims jump to the highest level in seven months. Kathleen Hays will be there to give us that.

Also, they are setting the stage for tonight`s first presidential debate, but do we already know the winner in November? Some say the economy is giving us some pretty strong clues as to who will win the White House.

And what are the five best stocks for the next five years? Today`s stock picker says stick with the big names.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

ROMANS: More evidence the consumer may be holding back. At the same the unemployment line, the longest in seven months and the government blames hurricanes. Kathleen Hays is here to take a look.

KATHLEEN HAYS, CNNfn ECONOMICS CORRESPONDENT: Well, we know hurricanes don`t help much when people are trying to get to work, when there`s power lines down, when the water is not running. Of course there could be some more people filing for unemployment benefits. But let me give you the numbers. And you see that all hurricanes are not. Jobless claims jumped by 18,000 to 369,000. That`s the highest level since about mid-February.

And, of course, it is fair to say, look, yes, we`ve had three weeks in a row now of claims moving higher. But we have also had these storms. That has to skew the numbers. Bottom line is that four-week moving average, actually this number overall is really kind of stuck in a range. If you just take this trend, it`s around 340,000, it isn`t going up, and it isn`t going down. It seems like the movement towards a healthier labor market, if you look just at claims, has stalled.

But it`s stalled at a decent level. Another thing to add in here though is the help wanted index from the conference board, which measures column inches of help wanted ads across the country, unchanged again in August. The same level as last year. And Ken Goldstein over at the conference board says that this stagnant labor market is eating into consumer confidence. That`s something we saw earlier this week.

Speaking of the consumer, consumer spending out today. This is the broad measure of consumer spending, not just retail sales. Not just spending on items, on goods. This includes spending on airline tickets, doctors office, and education. A very broad measure. That number was flat. That`s not such a good number. Now of course, we did have two previous months of gains, maybe a lull isn`t surprising.

We do have wage growth boosting income. That`s the raw material for future spending. Maybe we`ll have a pickup. That is the big question now. One thing I can tell you is inflation is looking very flame in this report as it has in others. It looks like companies still don`t have pricing power. Christine. Because a (INAUDIBLE), if the price is too high, we say no thanks. I don`t want to buy it.

ROMANS: Right. Absolutely. Ok, now the economy not the first focus of the first presidential debate.

HAYS: How could they not? How could they go past the economy?

ROMANS: They`ll get to it. They`ll get to it.

HAYS: The third debate. Tonight of course, it`s foreign policy and homeland security. But it`s still about money, isn`t it? Worried about the budget deficit. We`re worried about the dollar cost and things. So we just wanted to give you some facts on the figures.

In the 2005 fiscal year budget, national security, think of the Pentagon, think of troops, think of new planes, all kind of things, that`s $420 billion. The war next year, or this fiscal year I should say is going to cost us $50 billion, at least. Homeland security comes in at $32 billion for a total of $500 billion. And that is about one-fifth, isn`t it, of the total budget of $2.4 trillion. So that does put it in perspective. It also shows really, how important this is.

Everybody would say whatever it costs. Whatever it costs for homeland security. Whatever it costs to be strong in the world. It is a cost though. And spending that money of course takes money away from other things.

ROMANS: Jobs also a big on the campaign trail. October 8th is the last jobs report before the election.

HAYS: Isn`t that interesting? Yes. So this is the last one we`ll get to see. And then I think we get one more GDP report as well. And it will be the first look at third quarter GDP. I think we also get that before-

ROMANS: Very important.

HAYS: It will be very important.

ROMANS: It`s interesting. Because depending on which camp you talk to. You talk to the Kerry camp and they`ll say things like 3.9 million Americans have simply exhausted their unemployment benefits over the last year. So when you talk about unemployment rates, you talk about people getting jobs, keep in mind, there are almost 4 million people who simply ran out of unemployment benefits and can`t find jobs.

But the Bush administration will say look, the momentum has been good over the past year. So it`s so political --

HAYS: And we don`t know for sure. I will say though, I think what`s interesting when Dick Cheney says don`t worry, lots of those people are selling things on eBay [Company: eBay Inc.; Ticker: EBAY ; URL: http://www.ebay.com/] . I would say, Mr. Cheney though, is that a sign of health that people are making a living by selling stuff on eBay, or a sign that they don`t have anything else to do? Kind of arguing to the Kerry point. But it`s --

ROMANS: It`s certainly not the best job market in 20 years. It`s not the worst job market in three generations.

HAYS: That`s right.

ROMANS: Somewhere in the middle. All right. Thank you very much Kathleen.

Still ahead on STREETSWEEP, fresh questions about Fannie Mae`s accounting drag its shares to the lowest level in a year. And the next step may be a criminal case.

Also, Merck gets high marks for the way it`s handling the Vioxx crisis. Can the company recover?

With a few minutes left until the closing bell, stocks are down. The Dow down 59 points, 10,076.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

ROMANS: Violence took a heavy toll in Iraq and in the Middle East. In Iraq, multiple car bombs rocked the capital killing 44 people, most of them children. That makes September the worst month for car bombs to date. More casualties came from a U.S. air strike in Fallujah, and violence near Mosul.

Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld acknowledged that violence is escalating, and said he expects it to get even worse as Iraqi elections approach. One Iraqi official says the county`s security forces are preparing a major offensive against the insurgents.

A bloody day in Gaza as well, where Israeli soldiers tried to halt a series of rocket attacks by Palestinian militants. In one marketplace, civilians were caught in the crossfire. A senior commander for Hamas said Israeli troops must retreat from the battle sites if they want the rocket attacks to stop.

And residents of Washington State are keeping a wary eye on the Cascades. The area around Mount St. Helens is under a volcano advisory. Geologists say the volcano could erupt in coming days or weeks. Officials say the damage could be minimal or moderate, but note that seismic activity has been rising steadily.

Back in the markets now. For the third time this week, one of our five for five stock pickers is recommending Pfizer as a stock for the long term. Richard Steinberg says investors should focus on mega large cap stocks. He also has four other picks to share with u this afternoon. We`re looking for five great stocks for the next five years. He joins me now from (INAUDIBLE) Florida.

Welcome to the program.

RICHARD STEINBERG, STEINBERG GLOBAL ASSET MANAGEMENT: Hey Christine, good to see you again.

ROMANS: Let`s talk first about Pfizer. Because what better day for you to come and say you think investors for the long-term should be buying Pfizer. It`s up today. A lot of people are talking about it and its drug Celebrex, because of what`s happening with Vioxx and Merck.

STEINBERG: Right. Do I have blood here? Because we also own a lot of Merck. I had an anvil fall on my head today.

ROMANS: Oh man. What are you going to do -- first of all, what are going to do with your Merck shares? Are you going to get out, or are you going to buy more here? Because it`s pretty cheap.

STEINBERG: We were on the conference call. And if you remember, about a year or so ago, you and I had Ray Gilmartin on your show.

ROMANS: That`s right.

STEINBERG: I think for now we`re going to sit tight and let things settle in. And look to just kind of analyze things as they go on. And not panic out of the name. But Pfizer still has a great franchise. They`re going to earn over $2.36 next year. We`re looking for companies that are either number one or number two market share in their markets now.

They were number one or two. And Celebrex, now there`s only one left really. So I think that that $2.36 could be light. And it could be a lot higher. And I think the pipeline still is very strong for Pfizer. It`s trading at 13 multiple. Good yield. I think that`s also a trend we have to look for, is getting paid to wait.

ROMANS: All right. Let`s talk about General Electric [Company: General Electric Company; Ticker: GE; URL: http://www.ge.com/] ; It`s also on your list. It`s another name that someone mentioned earlier this week too. So this is a big mega cap name. It`s got exposure to a whole bunch of different businesses, from jet engines, to the media. Why do you like it?

STEINBERG: Well, if we get back to our five-year theme of having globally diversified businesses, GE is a basically a bet that the long-term global economy continues to grow. They`re going to earn $1.78 this year. The six-sigma approach of getting out of businesses that they shouldn`t be in continues to work well.

Jeffrey Immelt`s doing an excellent job of kind of reining things in. The yield`s 2-plus percent. And I think it`s a name that over a long-term gives you broad exposure. And a name that of you have a long enough time horizon, like five years, you should own.

ROMANS: This is a name that also gives you a broad global exposure as well. I mean, I know this is a big player in the global outsourcing business.

STEINBERG: IBM, absolutely. They`ll going to earn $5.50 next year. Stocks relatively cheap. Cap ex spending and --

ROMANS: You`re talking about IBM [Company: International Business Machines Corporation; Ticker: IBM; URL: http://www.ibm.com/] here or GE?

STEINBERG: Oh, I`m sorry, GE, I`m sorry. GE global outsourcing is still a big deal. But I think it`s more about getting some of the problems out of the way that they have, where they`ve had with power generation and aircrafts.

ROMANS: All right. You mentioned IBM. Another big tech name. Another very well known blue chip name. In the papers in the news today because of a settlement, a payment, because of the way it sort of switched over some of its retirees pensions. Are you concerned about it?

STEINBERG: I`m not concerned about the retirees. There`s always kind of complaining when things get changed a bit. But the long-term story with IBM is really more about the -- their ability to have a smoother revenue stream than most tech companies, because of the recurring revenues from consulting and services.

Citigroup [Company: Citigroup Inc.; Ticker: C; URL: http://www.citi.com/] . Sally Krawcheck. What do you think about that move? Some changes over at Citi lately. Are you interested in Citigroup because of the way this management is positioned? Are you interested in it because it`s the biggest player out there? Why do you like it?

STEINBERG: Global reach in financial services, 10 times earnings, great yield. Obviously, with the change in interest rates that are occurring, I believe that their balance sheet liability exposure is well positioned for a bump up in rates. And again, if I look out five years, and I want global exposure, two names, I think Citigroup has to be a core holding.

ROMANS: Target [Company: Target Corporation; Ticker: TGT; URL: http://www.targetcorp.com/] is a number two to Wal-Mart [Company: Wal-Mart Stores Inc.; Ticker: WMT ; URL:   http://www.wal-mart.com/] . You know, Wal- Mart seems to gobble up everything every place it goes. It`s the biggest retailer. The biggest everything. How can Target position itself with Wal-Mart sort of as the big you know, gorilla in the field?

STEINBERG: I think this is the PT boat outmaneuvering the large aircraft carrier right now. Target is going to earn $2.60 this year. They`ve shed Marshall Fields , which was kind of the albatross. And I think that as we go through kind of these pitfalls and ups and downs in the economy, the market will continue to drive towards that discount retailing.

Wal-Mart is still the 800-pound gorilla, but doesn`t mean the baby gorilla can`t make money along the way. I think in the short run, especially with some of the problems that they have in litigation, and litigation payments that Wal-Mart has, that they`re going to be able to make a lot of money.

ROMANS: Overall Richard, tell us a little bit about what kinds of criteria you use for picking stocks. Talk to our viewer, the average investor who is looking out for five years trying to build some sort of portfolio.

STEINBERG: So the first thing that you need to do is you need to know what you own. The second thing is, I think if you focus on large, easy to understand companies, you have a much better ability to have successful performance and not get caught up in the latest technological changes.

The other thing is you want to focus on companies that can dominate their market share, that have a diversified business model, and have very strong management. You have to be able to distinguish the difference between owning a good company, and owning a good stock.

If you can bring those pieces together and focus on also getting paid to wait with some dividends where possible, I think, as we go through a transition in the economy over the next five years, we`ll, -- you`ll be successful.

ROMANS: Richard Steinberg thanks so much for joining us. We`re going to put those stock picks on our web site if anybody missed them.

Still ahead, President George Bush and Senator John Kerry square off tonight in the first presidential debate. Their subject -- foreign policy.

Plus, a long-term look at Merck. Vioxx is one problem. But here`s another. Its patent for top-selling Zocor expires in about a year.

Moments to go to the closing bell, the Dow Jones industrial average down 71 points.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

urn:contentItem:4PN6-BW90-TXXD-80W4-00000-00New York Stock Exchange Update; Word From The Floor; Hays Wire; 5 for 5, CNNfn2004-09-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:25ZLexisNexisNew York Stock Exchange Update; Word From The Floor; Hays Wire; 5 for 5, CNNfnABSTRACT

A medication used to relieve pain for millions of people is now a source of pain for the company that makes it. Merck [Company: Merck & Co. Inc.; Ticker: MRK ; URL: http://www.merck.com/] is pulling its arthritis drug Vioxx effective immediately. And investors are pulling out of Merck. That stock is down 27 percent. That`s roughly $27 billion of lost market cap. The stock now at the lowest price in eight years.

FULL TEXT

CHRISTINE ROMANS, CNNfn ANCHOR, STREET SWEEP: I`m Christine Romans in New York. Counting down to the closing bell on the final day of the third quarter on Wall Street. The Dow is lower. This is STREETSWEEP.

A medication used to relieve pain for millions of people is now a source of pain for the company that makes it. Merck [Company: Merck & Co. Inc.; Ticker: MRK ; URL: http://www.merck.com/] is pulling its arthritis drug Vioxx effective immediately. And investors are pulling out of Merck. That stock is down 27 percent. That`s roughly $27 billion of lost market cap. The stock now at the lowest price in eight years.

Fred Katayama was at a Merck press conference earlier this morning. He joins us now with the details. Fred?

FRED KATAYAMA, CNNfn CORRESPONDENT: Well, Christine, the more than a million arthritis patients in the U.S. now taking Vioxx will soon have to stop taking it. It`s manufacturer Merck is pulling Vioxx off the world- wide market. The company made the decision after clinical tests results showed the drug raised the risk of heart attacks and strokes.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

RAYMOND GILMARTIN, CEO, MERCK: Importantly, in the first 18 months of the study, there is no difference in the risk for heart attack or stroke in patients taking either Vioxx or placebo. Beginning after 18 months, however, the risk of a cardiovascular event did increase among those on Vioxx. Accordingly, we are voluntarily withdrawing Vioxx effective today.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

KATAYAMA: The bombshell announcement came just weeks after Merck had insisted Vioxx was safe. An FDA study had showed that patients taking high doses of Vioxx had a three-times greater chance of a heart attack than those not taking painkillers. But today the Food and Drug Administration said Merck did the right thing in reporting its findings. And it said it would closely monitor other arthritis drugs for similar side effects.

But Merck`s investors got burned. Shares of the drug company sank to their lowest levels in nearly a decade. The Vioxx withdrawal will cut into Merck`s profits this year. It`s $2.5 billion in revenues make up more than a tenth of the company`s sales. For now, patients on Vioxx can switch to other arthritis drugs like Celebrex.

Merck says it`s clinical results do not necessarily apply to other drugs in it`s class. But some analysts say Merck`s findings might make patients more cautious about taking other arthritis drugs.

ROMANS: OK. Let`s talk about the company. Let`s talk about the executives of the company. Ray Gilmartin, the CEO at that press conference this morning. Even before this happened, there had been people on the street who have been saying the performance of the company was sub par and maybe he should resign. What do you say?

KATAYAMA: Well, the reporters did ask him at the press conference if he was going to step down. He said no.

ROMANS: What are the analysts saying about how well he`s handling this crisis?

KATAYAMA: Some people say it was good that he stepped up and voluntarily pushed forward instead of waiting for the Food and Drug Administration to mandate a withdrawal. So in a sense, the positive spin on this story is that Pfizer [Company: Pfizer Inc.; Ticker: PFE; URL: http://www.pfizer.com/] took an active role in trying to -- you know, what people call a proactive role in trying to withdraw the drugs from the market before it created any harm.

But as you know, he`s been under a lot of pressure. He said he`s not going to resign.

ROMANS: This has been a heavily advertised drug. A lot of people now -- what are people supposed to do who are on the drug? And I can`t imagine how this is going to change the entire landscape for arthritis medications. And for the other companies that make these medications.

KATAYAMA: The people who are currently on the drug, they are advised to stop taking it. Right now Pfizer is working with the medical profession to try to get those drugs off the shelves and to get patients worldwide to stop taking this drug. Now there are other options for those patients. That`s the good news.

For example, they can turn to Celebrex, which is made by Pfizer. And there are other arthritis drugs on the market. And drug analysts feel that the company that will benefit the most out of this is Pfizer, because Celebrex is currently the best-selling arthritis drug on the market. Another beneficiary Chris, according to analyst in Merrill Lynch could be Schering- Plough.

ROMANS: Oh really?

KATAYAMA: And the reason is because now that Merck is really under pressure, remember, Merck has had a weak pipeline for several years.

ROMANS: Sure.

KATAYAMA: The analyst community has said Merck you have to combine with some other company the way that Pfizer bought out Warner-Lambert. We saw consolidation in the sector. Merck said, no we`re going to go it alone. Well, the Merrill analyst thinks that is going to pressure Merck to perhaps swallow another company, possibly Schering-Plough. You know, you got to fill that pipeline.

ROMANS: Absolutely.

KATAYAMA: Especially with the $2.5 billion in revenues taken out with this Vioxx drug.

ROMANS: A very big story. And I am sure we are not going to hear the last of it. All right. Thanks, Fred Katayama.

Merck`s top competitor in the arthritis medication field as Fred said, Pfizer. And it`s shares are higher today. Shares of Pfizer, which makes Celebrex up more than 1 percent.

Later in the program in our five for five segment, I`ll speak with a money manager who says Pfizer is a good pick for your portfolio over the next five years.

Merck`s loss today accounts for the entire drop in the Dow Industrials. Without it, the market would actually be up. Rhonda Schaffler live at the New York Stock Exchange. Rhonda?

RHONDA SCHAFFLER, NEW YORK STOCK EXCHANGE: Hi Christine.

Well, as you can imagine, this story really has taken stage on Wall Street. And not only is the broader market OK. Advancers are actually leading decliners by a 3/2 margin. We have a situation here where Merck is going to impact the numbers for the quarter for the Dow with this very dramatic close that we are expecting here.

Obviously, it will be difficult for any sort of recovery late in the day. NASDAQ, though, is in a lot better shape when we look at the chart. Again because remember, there is underlying strength in the market today. You are just not seeing it with the Dow because of Merck, which is dominating the action here. Merck, in fact, is the most actively traded stock at the New York Stock Exchange today. Down about 26 percent.

This will also be one of these days where this action will go in the record books. Because at this point, the trading in Merck is on tap to have one of the top 10 one-day volumes in a single stock. So this has been a very huge story here. You are looking at how some of the other drug stocks are faring. Obviously we`ve touch on Pfizer and Celebrex, which would benefit from this news from Merck.

There are other big stories too. Fannie Mae [Company: Fannie Mae ; Ticker: FNM ; URL: http://www.fanniemae.com/] for instance. This one has been a big story it seems every day. That stock is off again as the Justice Department has opened an investigation into possible accounting fraud at that company. This comes after Fannie Mae`s government regulators said last week the company may have manipulated it`s books. The agency also now will issue monthly reports regarding the company`s capital. Used to send out those reports quarterly.

Also on the earnings front, Fresh Del Monte [Company: Fresh Del Monte Produce Inc.; Ticker: FDP; URL: http://www.freshdelmonte.com/] produce cut its earnings forecast for the full year by some 50 cents a share. Del Monte now sees 2004 earnings of $2.05 to $2.15 a share. It cites lower banana prices, less profitable shares of domestic melons, go figure. And hurricane-ravaged Florida tomatoes. All those reasons sending the stock sharply lower.

And now let`s look at Gateway [Company: Gateway Inc.; Ticker: GTW; URL: http://www.gateway.com/]. A little bit of a different picture here. Gateway is unveiling a new line of desktop PCs. Customers will be able to customize their new models. Gateway also says the higher end models will have a different technology than previous systems. Earlier this month Gateway said it was going to shift its focus back to PCs. Wall Street applauding that particular piece of news. Christine?

ROMANS: All right. Rhonda Schaffler, thanks very much Rhonda, on as you said, a very big news day.

That stunning Merck decline comes on the final day of a rough quarter for a lot of stock investors. Susan Green of IDI joins me now from the New York Stock Exchange. First, you heard Rhonda say this could be one of the top 10 trading days of any individual stock in Merck. A huge move. Susan, give us a little bit of a sense how unusual it is to see a Dow component lose a quarter of its value in one day.

SUSAN GREEN, IDI: It`s actually very unusual. Something we haven`t seen in quite a while. If you take the 87 or 88 million shares out of the Dow today we`re still looking at roughly 1.35 billion shares today, which is pretty interesting. But to see a company lose almost 30 percent of its market value is extraordinary. It doesn`t happen very often.

And I think on the point of positive to positivity here, if you look at the way the stock opened, it opened and traded within a point-and-a-quarter all day long. So that 88 million shares has basically been range bound on the opening and thereafter, which is very unusual.

ROMANS: Talk to us a little bit about this coming on the last day of a quarter. I mean, you have got a lot of mutual funds that own this. "Morningstar" was telling us that Magellan . For those of you out there who own Magellan the mutual fund, or Vanguard, you are looking at you know a concentration of this particular stock in your portfolio. It`s the last day of the quarter. So it`s tough to sort of get out of a position, isn`t it?

GREEN: Well, it would be tough to get out of the position if there was no volume. That could be the reason for the stock opening at a range, staying there all day long, and trading the size that it`s trading today. They took us at a level to get it to trade. End of the quarter, people want out. New money going in. There`s a rotation going on in the stock. It needs to happen today. This is important.

They`ve managed to get it done. Then you also have to think about the fact that the Dow should probably be up on the day because of Merck being in the component, and just the way we`re seeing the market now. The money flow is directly into the market at the end of the quarter, which is actually pretty positive.

ROMANS: That`s a really good way to look at it, stripping out Merck. Merck right now is accounting for some 80, almost 90 points of Dow. The downside if you took it out, you`d actually have the Dow up a little bit.

OK. Another little factoid I wanted to give you. The Nasdaq on track for its worst quarter, even if it closed higher today, on track for its worst quarter in two years. It was a tough quarter for tech stocks. Do you feel as though there could be some momentum in the other direction for the fourth quarter?

GREEN: Well, they actually tried doing it. I mean, they got the semiconductor index, the stocks down to a level where it started trading based on the trading range. So technically, it feels as if tech stocks are actually bottomed out. But it wasn`t enough. There`s not enough momentum going into these stocks for the end of the quarter to get us going.

As we know, tech, and Nasdaq is generally tech driven, is basically forward looking. So what we need to see, management start coming out with earnings within the next two weeks is what the guidance is going to be. That`s what the focus is going to be on. That`s the only thing that`s going to get us through to the fourth quarter.

ROMANS: All right. Susan Green on the final day of a quarter. Thanks for stopping by Susan.

GREEN: Thanks Christine.

ROMANS: Coming up next on STREETSWEEP, more evidence the consumer is cutting back. At the same time jobless claims jump to the highest level in seven months. Kathleen Hays will be there to give us that.

Also, they are setting the stage for tonight`s first presidential debate, but do we already know the winner in November? Some say the economy is giving us some pretty strong clues as to who will win the White House.

And what are the five best stocks for the next five years? Today`s stock picker says stick with the big names.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

ROMANS: More evidence the consumer may be holding back. At the same the unemployment line, the longest in seven months and the government blames hurricanes. Kathleen Hays is here to take a look.

KATHLEEN HAYS, CNNfn ECONOMICS CORRESPONDENT: Well, we know hurricanes don`t help much when people are trying to get to work, when there`s power lines down, when the water is not running. Of course there could be some more people filing for unemployment benefits. But let me give you the numbers. And you see that all hurricanes are not. Jobless claims jumped by 18,000 to 369,000. That`s the highest level since about mid-February.

And, of course, it is fair to say, look, yes, we`ve had three weeks in a row now of claims moving higher. But we have also had these storms. That has to skew the numbers. Bottom line is that four-week moving average, actually this number overall is really kind of stuck in a range. If you just take this trend, it`s around 340,000, it isn`t going up, and it isn`t going down. It seems like the movement towards a healthier labor market, if you look just at claims, has stalled.

But it`s stalled at a decent level. Another thing to add in here though is the help wanted index from the conference board, which measures column inches of help wanted ads across the country, unchanged again in August. The same level as last year. And Ken Goldstein over at the conference board says that this stagnant labor market is eating into consumer confidence. That`s something we saw earlier this week.

Speaking of the consumer, consumer spending out today. This is the broad measure of consumer spending, not just retail sales. Not just spending on items, on goods. This includes spending on airline tickets, doctors office, and education. A very broad measure. That number was flat. That`s not such a good number. Now of course, we did have two previous months of gains, maybe a lull isn`t surprising.

We do have wage growth boosting income. That`s the raw material for future spending. Maybe we`ll have a pickup. That is the big question now. One thing I can tell you is inflation is looking very flame in this report as it has in others. It looks like companies still don`t have pricing power. Christine. Because a (INAUDIBLE), if the price is too high, we say no thanks. I don`t want to buy it.

ROMANS: Right. Absolutely. Ok, now the economy not the first focus of the first presidential debate.

HAYS: How could they not? How could they go past the economy?

ROMANS: They`ll get to it. They`ll get to it.

HAYS: The third debate. Tonight of course, it`s foreign policy and homeland security. But it`s still about money, isn`t it? Worried about the budget deficit. We`re worried about the dollar cost and things. So we just wanted to give you some facts on the figures.

In the 2005 fiscal year budget, national security, think of the Pentagon, think of troops, think of new planes, all kind of things, that`s $420 billion. The war next year, or this fiscal year I should say is going to cost us $50 billion, at least. Homeland security comes in at $32 billion for a total of $500 billion. And that is about one-fifth, isn`t it, of the total budget of $2.4 trillion. So that does put it in perspective. It also shows really, how important this is.

Everybody would say whatever it costs. Whatever it costs for homeland security. Whatever it costs to be strong in the world. It is a cost though. And spending that money of course takes money away from other things.

ROMANS: Jobs also a big on the campaign trail. October 8th is the last jobs report before the election.

HAYS: Isn`t that interesting? Yes. So this is the last one we`ll get to see. And then I think we get one more GDP report as well. And it will be the first look at third quarter GDP. I think we also get that before-

ROMANS: Very important.

HAYS: It will be very important.

ROMANS: It`s interesting. Because depending on which camp you talk to. You talk to the Kerry camp and they`ll say things like 3.9 million Americans have simply exhausted their unemployment benefits over the last year. So when you talk about unemployment rates, you talk about people getting jobs, keep in mind, there are almost 4 million people who simply ran out of unemployment benefits and can`t find jobs.

But the Bush administration will say look, the momentum has been good over the past year. So it`s so political --

HAYS: And we don`t know for sure. I will say though, I think what`s interesting when Dick Cheney says don`t worry, lots of those people are selling things on eBay [Company: eBay Inc.; Ticker: EBAY ; URL: http://www.ebay.com/] . I would say, Mr. Cheney though, is that a sign of health that people are making a living by selling stuff on eBay, or a sign that they don`t have anything else to do? Kind of arguing to the Kerry point. But it`s --

ROMANS: It`s certainly not the best job market in 20 years. It`s not the worst job market in three generations.

HAYS: That`s right.

ROMANS: Somewhere in the middle. All right. Thank you very much Kathleen.

Still ahead on STREETSWEEP, fresh questions about Fannie Mae`s accounting drag its shares to the lowest level in a year. And the next step may be a criminal case.

Also, Merck gets high marks for the way it`s handling the Vioxx crisis. Can the company recover?

With a few minutes left until the closing bell, stocks are down. The Dow down 59 points, 10,076.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

ROMANS: Violence took a heavy toll in Iraq and in the Middle East. In Iraq, multiple car bombs rocked the capital killing 44 people, most of them children. That makes September the worst month for car bombs to date. More casualties came from a U.S. air strike in Fallujah, and violence near Mosul.

Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld acknowledged that violence is escalating, and said he expects it to get even worse as Iraqi elections approach. One Iraqi official says the county`s security forces are preparing a major offensive against the insurgents.

A bloody day in Gaza as well, where Israeli soldiers tried to halt a series of rocket attacks by Palestinian militants. In one marketplace, civilians were caught in the crossfire. A senior commander for Hamas said Israeli troops must retreat from the battle sites if they want the rocket attacks to stop.

And residents of Washington State are keeping a wary eye on the Cascades. The area around Mount St. Helens is under a volcano advisory. Geologists say the volcano could erupt in coming days or weeks. Officials say the damage could be minimal or moderate, but note that seismic activity has been rising steadily.

Back in the markets now. For the third time this week, one of our five for five stock pickers is recommending Pfizer as a stock for the long term. Richard Steinberg says investors should focus on mega large cap stocks. He also has four other picks to share with u this afternoon. We`re looking for five great stocks for the next five years. He joins me now from (INAUDIBLE) Florida.

Welcome to the program.

RICHARD STEINBERG, STEINBERG GLOBAL ASSET MANAGEMENT: Hey Christine, good to see you again.

ROMANS: Let`s talk first about Pfizer. Because what better day for you to come and say you think investors for the long-term should be buying Pfizer. It`s up today. A lot of people are talking about it and its drug Celebrex, because of what`s happening with Vioxx and Merck.

STEINBERG: Right. Do I have blood here? Because we also own a lot of Merck. I had an anvil fall on my head today.

ROMANS: Oh man. What are you going to do -- first of all, what are going to do with your Merck shares? Are you going to get out, or are you going to buy more here? Because it`s pretty cheap.

STEINBERG: We were on the conference call. And if you remember, about a year or so ago, you and I had Ray Gilmartin on your show.

ROMANS: That`s right.

STEINBERG: I think for now we`re going to sit tight and let things settle in. And look to just kind of analyze things as they go on. And not panic out of the name. But Pfizer still has a great franchise. They`re going to earn over $2.36 next year. We`re looking for companies that are either number one or number two market share in their markets now.

They were number one or two. And Celebrex, now there`s only one left really. So I think that that $2.36 could be light. And it could be a lot higher. And I think the pipeline still is very strong for Pfizer. It`s trading at 13 multiple. Good yield. I think that`s also a trend we have to look for, is getting paid to wait.

ROMANS: All right. Let`s talk about General Electric [Company: General Electric Company; Ticker: GE; URL: http://www.ge.com/] ; It`s also on your list. It`s another name that someone mentioned earlier this week too. So this is a big mega cap name. It`s got exposure to a whole bunch of different businesses, from jet engines, to the media. Why do you like it?

STEINBERG: Well, if we get back to our five-year theme of having globally diversified businesses, GE is a basically a bet that the long-term global economy continues to grow. They`re going to earn $1.78 this year. The six-sigma approach of getting out of businesses that they shouldn`t be in continues to work well.

Jeffrey Immelt`s doing an excellent job of kind of reining things in. The yield`s 2-plus percent. And I think it`s a name that over a long-term gives you broad exposure. And a name that of you have a long enough time horizon, like five years, you should own.

ROMANS: This is a name that also gives you a broad global exposure as well. I mean, I know this is a big player in the global outsourcing business.

STEINBERG: IBM, absolutely. They`ll going to earn $5.50 next year. Stocks relatively cheap. Cap ex spending and --

ROMANS: You`re talking about IBM [Company: International Business Machines Corporation; Ticker: IBM; URL: http://www.ibm.com/] here or GE?

STEINBERG: Oh, I`m sorry, GE, I`m sorry. GE global outsourcing is still a big deal. But I think it`s more about getting some of the problems out of the way that they have, where they`ve had with power generation and aircrafts.

ROMANS: All right. You mentioned IBM. Another big tech name. Another very well known blue chip name. In the papers in the news today because of a settlement, a payment, because of the way it sort of switched over some of its retirees pensions. Are you concerned about it?

STEINBERG: I`m not concerned about the retirees. There`s always kind of complaining when things get changed a bit. But the long-term story with IBM is really more about the -- their ability to have a smoother revenue stream than most tech companies, because of the recurring revenues from consulting and services.

Citigroup [Company: Citigroup Inc.; Ticker: C; URL: http://www.citi.com/] . Sally Krawcheck. What do you think about that move? Some changes over at Citi lately. Are you interested in Citigroup because of the way this management is positioned? Are you interested in it because it`s the biggest player out there? Why do you like it?

STEINBERG: Global reach in financial services, 10 times earnings, great yield. Obviously, with the change in interest rates that are occurring, I believe that their balance sheet liability exposure is well positioned for a bump up in rates. And again, if I look out five years, and I want global exposure, two names, I think Citigroup has to be a core holding.

ROMANS: Target [Company: Target Corporation; Ticker: TGT; URL: http://www.targetcorp.com/] is a number two to Wal-Mart [Company: Wal-Mart Stores Inc.; Ticker: WMT ; URL:   http://www.wal-mart.com/] . You know, Wal- Mart seems to gobble up everything every place it goes. It`s the biggest retailer. The biggest everything. How can Target position itself with Wal-Mart sort of as the big you know, gorilla in the field?

STEINBERG: I think this is the PT boat outmaneuvering the large aircraft carrier right now. Target is going to earn $2.60 this year. They`ve shed Marshall Fields , which was kind of the albatross. And I think that as we go through kind of these pitfalls and ups and downs in the economy, the market will continue to drive towards that discount retailing.

Wal-Mart is still the 800-pound gorilla, but doesn`t mean the baby gorilla can`t make money along the way. I think in the short run, especially with some of the problems that they have in litigation, and litigation payments that Wal-Mart has, that they`re going to be able to make a lot of money.

ROMANS: Overall Richard, tell us a little bit about what kinds of criteria you use for picking stocks. Talk to our viewer, the average investor who is looking out for five years trying to build some sort of portfolio.

STEINBERG: So the first thing that you need to do is you need to know what you own. The second thing is, I think if you focus on large, easy to understand companies, you have a much better ability to have successful performance and not get caught up in the latest technological changes.

The other thing is you want to focus on companies that can dominate their market share, that have a diversified business model, and have very strong management. You have to be able to distinguish the difference between owning a good company, and owning a good stock.

If you can bring those pieces together and focus on also getting paid to wait with some dividends where possible, I think, as we go through a transition in the economy over the next five years, we`ll, -- you`ll be successful.

ROMANS: Richard Steinberg thanks so much for joining us. We`re going to put those stock picks on our web site if anybody missed them.

Still ahead, President George Bush and Senator John Kerry square off tonight in the first presidential debate. Their subject -- foreign policy.

Plus, a long-term look at Merck. Vioxx is one problem. But here`s another. Its patent for top-selling Zocor expires in about a year.

Moments to go to the closing bell, the Dow Jones industrial average down 71 points.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)
