urn:contentItem:5YHN-13S1-F0JV-82N2-00000-00NHSX marks the spot: diplomat-turned-digital chief Matthew Gould talks patient data and AI2020-03-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:25ZLexisNexisNHSX marks the spot: diplomat-turned-digital chief Matthew Gould talks patient data and AI

In February 2019, Matt Hancock announced plans for a new innovation agency in the NHS. A year on, its chief executive, Matthew Gould, talks to Beckie Smith about health data, listening to patients, and his move from diplomacy to digital

Photo AdobeStock

This interview was conducted before the UK's coronavirus outbreak

You could say Matthew Gould's journey to leading NHSX started three and a half thousand miles away. A career diplomat, Gould was serving as the British ambassador to Israel when he helped to launch the UK-Israel Technologies Hub - an initiative run out of the British Embassy in Tel Aviv to forge technology partnerships between UK and Israeli companies.

"I spent a lot of time building links between the UK and Israel in tech. The Israeli tech scene is extraordinary," Gould says.

Israel was his last international posting - previously he had spent time in Islamabad, Washington, Manila and Tehran, during which time he was sent to negotiate the release of a group of marines and sailors who had been taken prisoner by the Iranian Revolutionary Guard. ("When you get off a plane and into a taxi and turn on the BBC News, and item number one on the worldwide news is the fact that you've just got off a plane, you feel very much like you are the centre of things and need to deliver," he says.)

RELATED CONTENT

Andrew Greenway: How GDS conquered the world

Interview: GDS head Alison Pritchard on ministerial change, the spending review and the benefits of comedy

Did the Government Transformation Strategy point the way to the future?

Rather than go back to the Foreign Office when he returned to the UK in 2015, he became director of cybersecurity at the Cabinet Office - a move in part spurred by his involvement in the tech partnership in Israel, he says.

"That in turn led me to become the government's first director general for digital policy. And then having lived it on a national and policy level, the prospect of doing it for real in a very sort of punchy way here [for the NHS] was too good an opportunity to pass up."

Gould became chief executive of NHSX - an organisation that sits across NHS England and the Department for Health and Social Care - last May, three months after health secretary Matt Hancock announced its creation. Its aim, according to Hancock, is to "bring strategy, leadership and technical expertise to... the world's most exciting public sector digital transformation project".

The role of NHSX - and its relationship to existing bodies like NHS Digital, which provides tech and information systems to support healthcare - is not yet well understood by many outside the organisation. But when CSW puts this to the former ambassador, he says the two have very different roles to play.

"NHSX is the guiding mind at the centre: we are the centre for strategy, we hold the budgets, we set the policy and we commission from NHS Digital and from others like NHS Business Services Authority."

He refers to a speech by Hancock in January, which described NHS Digital and NHS BSA as the "tracks down which tech runs in the NHS". Gould adds: "So they are the core delivery partner for health and care."

"They do a lot of build, normally commissioned by us, so there is a clear distinction between our world and theirs. We haven't done a good enough job yet explaining that publicly - partly because we've been working out ourselves exactly how we want the delineation to work - but I think it is a familiar one. And I think it's useful. And I think it will be clear."

For now, the two words the public are likeliest to associate with NHSX would be "innovation" and "data". Last year headlines declared that the innovation body had taken control of industry access to patients' data and commercial deals with the NHS.

"I'm not sure I'd frame it quite like that," Gould says, choosing his words carefully. Rather, it provides policy and guidance on the use of data. NHSX is in the process of setting up a team known as the Centre for Expertise, whose job will include providing commercial and legal advice to NHS organisations signing data agreements, developing standard contracts and guidance, and advising on ensuring deals benefit the health service.

And NHSX has worked with NHS Digital and with the Office for Life Sciences - which straddles DHSC and the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy, and which champions research, innovation and tech in healthcare - to come up with a set of principles to govern the use of patient data, including in commercial transactions.

"In all this, we're very clear, first of all, that the privacy of patient data is absolutely paramount. We need to keep patients with us and we need to keep staff with us, so we can't do anything that erodes trust," Gould says.

"People who are trying to care for patients at their most vulnerable are doing so with a hand tied behind their back because we haven't found a way to make sure that the information about the patient can flow in the way that it needs to"

The principles establish, among other things, that any use of patient data must have an "explicit aim to improve the health, welfare and/or care of patients in the NHS"; that the terms of data-sharing agreements should include "quantifiable and explicit benefits for patients"; and that agreements should be transparent and must not undermine the work of the health service.

And there is one that Gould calls an "absolute": no hospital or trust can sign a deal giving a research group or company exclusive access to its patient data. "Because one of the things that is most valuable about the patient data that the NHS holds, is that it is a coherent set of 55 million people's records." Whittling away at the whole would undermine that value, he says.

"That's very corrosive. I don't think the public would support it, and I think it's damaging to the system. So we've laid down that rule."

But CSW wonders how many members of the public need to get as far as thinking about cohorts or exclusive agreements before they start to get nervous about how their data is used. The bigger worries for many people are twofold: that they won't be given a choice over what happens to their data, and that it could be traced back to them.

These aren't new worries. In 2016, the ill-fated care.data project, which was to extract anonymised records from GP surgeries into a central database, was closed after concerns about patient consent and confidentiality. But one need only look at the last year's worth of headlines to see that debate around the topic is not getting any less heated, and that some of the public already have already lost trust in what is happening to health data. In December, the Atlantic ran an article warning about the trend of big companies gathering up huge reams of health data - whether that's Apple gathering it directly through footstep and sleep trackers on people's iPhones, or Facebook's AI division working with radiologists to teach its machine-learning systems to read MRI scans. The headline? "Everyone should be worried by big tech's huge NHS data grab."

What does Gould think - should everyone be worried? "Well, I think what I would rather frame it as is: we should make sure that whatever we do is in line with the principles that we've set out," Gould says.

He says polling shows that while there will be people at either end of the spectrum of attitudes to data, "there's a large group of people in the middle... who are comfortable with their data being used to develop new treatments or therapies or whatever it is, as long as they are confident that it's being done in a way that sufficient benefit comes back to the NHS".

Indeed, a poll commissioned last year by the National Data Guardian Dame Fiona Caldicott - who advises and challenges the health and care system on safeguarding citizens' confidential information - found about seven in 10 people in England approved of partnerships that led to benefits like access to new technologies at a reduced cost and better patient care. In other areas the respondents were more evenly split: half said private companies should share in any profit generated from the deal, or that it was fair that they could; and exactly half were happy for the NHS to receive a one-off payment for access to data.

But the question that remains unaddressed is what to do about the cohort that Gould readily admits "would find it difficult to countenance their data being used for any purpose other than direct care". And another uncomfortable issue remains. What if the safeguards that Gould talks about don't work?

Last year, the Clinical Practice Research Datalink - part of the Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency, through which companies can buy patient data compiled from GP surgeries and hospitals for research purposes - changed the way it described the data it was selling from "anonymous" to "anonymised". The latter means it has been through processes to de-identify the patients it comes from - but there is no rigid standard for how this should be done.

Two days before CSW meets Gould, the Observer has published claims by anonymous "senior NHS figures" saying patient data sold for research via CPRD could be traced back to individual medical records.

Gould says he wouldn't want to comment on that story, given that it concerns a separate government body. "That was a particular data set belonging to a particular organisation. I wouldn't leap to a conclusion that because people have concerns, therefore it's not working."

But leaving aside that specific example, Gould acknowledges that when data is shared, "there is certainly a risk, depending on what data you have, that it can be pieced together and the process of anonymisation can be reversed."

He adds: "The question is, what systems and what safeguards do you have in place, so that you can be sufficiently confident that doesn't happen?"

The conversation returns to those safeguards when Gould speaks about another of NHSX's areas of expertise: artificial intelligence. Last September, the agency put out a report on good practice in AI, and is now in the process of setting up the National AI Lab.

The lab - a joint venture with the Accelerated Access Collaborative, which speeds up adoption of new treatments and tech in the NHS - will fund and develop artificial intelligence technologies to tackle tough healthcare challenges.

Gould says the lab is "starting to turn into more concrete plans" after the initial announcement of £250m to set it up last year. It will provide grants and facilitate cross-government, industry and academic collaborations on both mature and earlier-stage AI tech. The first tranche of funding, £114m, was announced in January.

But many people have mixed feelings about AI - not least because of a scandal that erupted when Royal Free Hospital handed over 1.6 million patients' health records to DeepMind, an AI company owned by Google, without their consent. The Information Commissioner's Office later found the hospital had failed to comply with data-protection legislation.

When CSW asks what some of the safeguards around data and AI should be, Gould says: "First of all, making sure that patient confidentiality is protected. So the data needs to be shared in a way that does that. If you allow an algorithm to span over a data set, have you done that in a way that protects patient data or puts it at risk? It's a technical question about how you structure the access."

Gould also acknowledges that "there is concern, both in the NHS and in the health tech community, that we haven't created coherent rules [for AI] that all fit together and give people the sense that there's cover for what they're doing".

In January, he convened a roundtable with the heads of 14 regulators and agencies involved in setting those rules - among them the MHRA, the information commissioner and the Health Research Authority. There they agreed to develop a platform to improve communication and share advice; create a regulatory "sandbox" where AI tech can be tested; and identify any gaps in regulation.

Gould is keen to realise what he says has been a long-held belief that "smart, innovation-friendly regulation that keeps citizens safe" will give the UK a competitive edge internationally. In other words, rules must be in place, but must not be so stringent that they "strangle the technology".

One risk the regulators will consider has become something of a ministerial talking point ever since then-PM Theresa May warned in Davos in 2018 that public bodies must ensure "algorithms don't perpetuate the human biases of their developers". She said the government's new Centre for Data Ethics and Innovation must tackle this.

Gould was on the team that set up the data-ethics centre in his previous role as director general for digital and media policy in the Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport, "so it's an area of thought that I've sort of brought with me to this job," he says. He wants AI to be used to tackle health inequalities, not worsen them.

"We're super mindful of the risks. There's no easy answer other than making sure that in regulation and practice, how we distribute resources and everything we do, the risks of exclusion, algorithmic bias and unintended consequences have been properly thought about, and we're doing it in a way that mitigates against those risks."

In October, NHSX published a report entitled "Artificial intelligence: how to get it right" setting out a framework for governance, models of "good AI" and guidelines for international best practice.

It's important to get this right because AI has huge potential benefits for the NHS, Gould says: "One of the exciting things about this is that some of the more mature and proven AI systems are precisely in those areas where the NHS has some of its most acute clinical shortages." AI programmes have been developed to read mammograms, and work with DeepMind at Moorfields Eye Hospital in London has led to a breakthrough tool to improve referrals for eye disease.

And there is also a wealth of non-clinical AI applications that could save the NHS time and money, Gould adds. A doctor at University College London Hospital has developed a system to predict when someone is likely to miss an appointment, which can then be used to send out prompts.

"It's really easy in a big system to lock yourself away at the centre and come up with the answers. But we won't get that right unless we listen to patients"

Gould is quick to point out that NHSX has another - rather less controversial - strand of work on data sharing, within the health service itself. "There's a lot of stress in the system around when it's okay to share patient data, even for direct care," he says.

In his early days in the role, Gould visited hospitals, GP surgeries and mental-health trusts and found that while it was technically possible to transfer patients' records from one of these bodies to another, it often wasn't happening because people were nervous about what would happen if they mistakenly shared the wrong data. Overwhelmed by seemingly conflicting guidance from different authorities, "some people have got a bit paralysed", he says.

NHSX is using what Gould calls its "convening power at the centre" to work with the National Data Guardian, the Information Commissioner's Office and NHS Digital to simplify the guidance "so that people know when it's safe to share and do so". He adds that this is a way NHSX "can directly impact on patient care and patient outcomes."

Gould became familiar with these data blockages on a personal level when his wife underwent treatment for breast cancer last year. "She was treated in four places, all local, none of which could speak to any of the others. She would have to carry around her scans, all her details, her test results; she would very often go and see the oncologist, who wouldn't be able to call up the results of the scans that he had ordered."

And Gould points out that not everyone can do that. In November, he announced NHSX was seeking two citizens to act as part-time advisers to ensure "the patient voice is properly built into everything we do". The agency will consult them during the conception, design, and development of new services.

Asked where the idea comes from, he says the "X" in the organisation's name stands for "user experience".

But actually, we won't get that right unless we are talking to users, and we're listening to patients, listening to staff and listening to people at the front line."

Every project should have a "patient voice" represented, he says, as well as the rigorous user research that already takes place. Otherwise, it's too easy to get caught up in what an organisation thinks patients need, even if that doesn't quite align with what they actually do need.

And so having those people who will make sure that in everything we do, we are focused on that and we remember why we're doing it and we skew what we do to the patient, I think can only be a good thing."

urn:contentItem:5RFH-DK31-DXH2-650S-00000-00Niall Ferguson is interviewed on BB TV.2018-01-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:25ZLexisNexisBLOOMBERG TV12:00 AM ESTNiall Ferguson, Julia ChatterleyNEWSInternational011878cb.550Niall Ferguson is interviewed on BB TV.Scarlet Fu

Niall Ferguson discusses politics.

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

NIALL FERGUSON, SENIOR FELLOW, HOOVER INSTITUTE, IS INTERVIEWED ON BB TV

JANUARY 18, 2018

SPEAKERS: NIALL FERGUSON, SENIOR FELLOW, HOOVER INSTITUTE

JULIA CHATTERLEY, BLOOMBERG NEWS

SCARLET FU, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] SCARLET FU, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: We want to bring in Niall Ferguson now. He's a Senior Fellow at the Hoover Institution at Stanford University, and a Senior Fellow at the Center for European state at Harvard. He is also the Author of the new book "The Square and the Tower. Networks empower from the Freemasons to Facebook.

Niall, thanks so much for joining us today.

NIALL FERGUSON, SENIOR FELLOW, HOOVER INSTITUTE: Great to be here.

FU: So we were just talking with Mike about President Trump and the looming government shutdown, if that happens. I want to start first with the presidency with you because in the past, you have called his presidency a comedy rather than a tragedy.

We've seen the administration scramble to perhaps a government shutdown, while at the same time saying may be a shutdown will be good. No matter what happens though, the base and his support is still there. Is it a wise move for the President right now to be pinning everything on the base staying with him as he touts the economy doing well and the stock market doing well, that can all go up in flames very quickly?

FERGUSON: It could. We all know that financial markets have a way of surprising that the bull market is forever. And there have been many people, my colleague at Harvard Martin Feldstein just this weekend in the general who've warned that a correction could come along and spoil that post of Donald Trumps argument.

But on the other hand if you look at that approval rating of his, it has not been taking off in the last few --

FU: From a little bit.

FERGUSON: From a historic a little bit. Remember he was the most unpopular President at the outset, since polling began. And he didn't get any more popular in his first year. But you begin to see the possible inflection point here as the economic good news just keeps on coming in. Plus it's a point that Trump is getting some wins on foreign policy, there aren't really anything like enough airtime.

I mean, he can change the policy in Iran and by the end of last year. Iran was in a state of upheaval. He took a much tougher line on North Korea. And now guess what, the North Korean's and South Korean's are making nice with one another.

So, one of the things that ordered by the Trump Presidencies is the way that he tend to shoot himself with that Twitter feed of his. And if he tweeted less and said fewer off the cuff races things that shocked so many peoples unjustly, we would be focusing more on the outcomes. We'd be focusing more on what's actually getting done.

And I think that would in fact reflect much better on him.

JULIA CHATTERLEY, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Do you think he's undermining he's own success?

FERGUSON: Well, I think the strategy is come up in raging liberal by being outrageous has one benefit. That is that seems to force Democrats to the left. And I think on sees (ph) this on the immigration issue. It's quite good from a Republicans strategic point of few, if the Democrats become more and more committed to sanctuary cities to the undocumented.

A lot of Republicans don't feel good about that at all. But my sense is that the cost and benefits of the President's populist outrage are kind of finally poised at this point. And I'm not sure he's necessary net better off with some of the most outrageous things that he said of late.

I think if he'd said much less over the last let say 12 months. And focus more on the achievements, he'd be riding higher in the polls.

CHATTERLEY: Do you think we've seen the loads as far as the politics concerns because as many aspects now already short-term and longer-term are playing to his favor, if we keep the tweeting aside?

FERGUSON: Right. I mean, one of the things I've tried to argue in The Square and the Tower is that we have a new kind of politics.

CHATTERLEY: Right.

FERGUSON: Which some of the still struggling to get ahead around is the public spear that's no longer dominated by network television, that's increasingly dominated by social media and the President has shown himself to have much better understanding not just the Twitter but the Facebook than his political rivals.

So one thing I did learn over two years of thinking and writing about Donald Trump is don't underestimate him and don't make the mistake of judging him by conventional measure. One thing I did recently was to just to run an experiment. I ask myself leaving aside personalities.

What presidency is this dislike? I mean this like the first year of Nixon and a lots of people have drawn that parallel, there's a lot of Democrats who would love this to be Watergate all over again is even the movie by Spielberg and go watch, you'd fantasize that.

You know, the Washington Post bringing down Donald Trump. It's not really like Nixon's first year at all, its much more like Bill Clinton first year. Go back and read woodward the agenda, change the names and you can have the version of what we've seen in the last year.

(CROSSTALK)

CHATTERLEY: We're going to talk more about (INAUDIBLE) Niall Ferguson, Author of "The Square and the Tower is staying with us.

(BREAK)

CHATTERLEY: We're back with Niall Ferguson. He is author of the new book "The Square and the Tower", Networks Empower from the Freemasons to Facebook. So we were just talking before about the sort of fundamental basis of this book and what it means and actually where Donald Trump sits in between the interplay between hierarchies in history and social network.

And how they've evolved overtime, he is someone who harness in a unique way like thinking political terms at least at that point in time, the power of social network and what that mean for democracy.

.FERGUSON: Well, in someway in the Brexit referendum was like the over the chart of the main show in 2016 because the leave campaign used Facebook as an advertising tool and just the way of the Trump campaign did.

But this book is about showing how social networks have always been there. It's not like Marks (ph) of Caberg (ph) invented them. All that Facebook did was to make them bigger and faster than they ever were before. But throughout history there have been periods when a new networks have come along and disrupted established hierarchies, those big tower of power that usually rule.

And my favorite example is from 500 years ago when the printing press completely disrupted European politics, causes the reformation Martin Luther without the printing press would just been birth at the state like hierarchy (ph). And we've never averted him.

CHATTERLEY: When you got the day off on Monday.

FERGUSON: It's true. So that certain that's another Martin Luther, that Martin the King introvertly and so had a social network, in the civil rights wouldn't have work if they haven't been this network of churches in the South that had the people organized and should cancel their commitment when it came to often very hazardous demonstration.

Social networks all that you don't need the internet to have them. All we've done is making them bigger and faster and I think more powerful than they've been certainly anytime in the last 400 or 300 years.

FU: And easier to corrupt as well, because of the platform.

FERGUSON: Right, this is the problem that makes it different from the age of printing press. There wasn't one person who owned over printing press is in 16th or 17th century Europe whereas social networks today are very concentrated and their ownership.

And this point of view, it's kind of extraordinary, these quasi-monopolies that have emerged online and seach, you've got Google retail, you've got Amazon, and of course in social media we've got Facebook.

This is extraordinary power. Facebook is the biggest content publisher in all of history. Zuckerberg is more powerful than William Randolph Hearst or Rupert Murdoch, any previous proprietor of the media organization.

And yet, Facebook is regulated as if it's a tech platform, not a content publisher. And that seem to me an extraordinary anomaly considering that 45 percent of Americans are getting their news from Facebook.

FU: Facebook is also reluctant to take on mental (ph) of assuming responsibility, should they?

CHATTERLEY: Also now.

FERGUSON: Well, they're indeed. And it's one of the key arguments that I think will play out in the coming years. Is it a content publisher? If it is, should it be liable for all the content that appears and the content, his vast in his content (ph).

I mean every now and then they'll say that they're hiring 10,000 people to bet the content. I mean come on the sheer scale of the content that is if you're Facebook he's going to require many, many more than 10,000 fact checkers.

I think this us a big issue. A lot of discussion on the big tech companies recently has been about anti-trust. I think that is a complete red herring. These are natural monopolies, you couldn't break them up. It's not going to happen. And the law, I don't think would support antitrust actions against these companies.

But I think the exemptions from liability for content that we're establishing mid 1990's when Facebook didn't even exist, those look like a vulnerability and I would just surprise if legislators and regulators begun to ask questions about that in the coming months

CHATTERLEY: What about for somebody like Amazon and the power that they continue to accrue or Google for that matter? Like who disrupts the ultimate disruptive that they've been in such a small space of time.

FERGUSON: Well, if I were Jeff Bezos, I wish I were. But I would be worried much more about my rivals in Asia. I'd be looking at Alibaba, I'd be looking at Jack Ma and I'd be thinking, you know, I thought I was going to own the rest of world and you would just of China.

I begin to wonder and I just was Hang Joe (ph) looking at what's going on. Alibaba could it be that the big Chinese tech companies are about to make a push for market share outside of China, and we might find the U.S. companies beginning to lose that. That would be my worry at Amazon.

FU: Niall Ferguson, Author of "The Square and the Tower" is going to stay with us.

(BREAK)

CHATTERLEY: Let's talk a bit more now about Bitcoin. We're back with Niall Ferguson. He says Bitcoin mega pot but the revolution will go on.

FERGUSON: Well, I said that when it was around about I think 1900 and it did go drop (ph). I have to tell about the story --

FU: You should be trading.

FERGUSON: Well, I don't know. The first thing should be trading is my son. So when he's 15th, it's now 18th now some back he said to me "Dad, you really should buy Bitcoin." And pompously I Professor Ferguson says "Young man, what do you know about financial history, this can never work. And I would call Jamie Dimon I almost said tulips (ph).

Well, I kind of learn the hard way. He was right. And I can got -- that caught up last year and began to really think about this. And we're amidst of an Amazing financial revolution which isn't just about Bitcoin. It's about Blockchain generally and what Blockchain can do.

I think a lot of people have got, you got confused by the term cryptocurrency. And because I'm not sure that we're going to produce a new form of money this way. But we have produced, what Bitcoin has produced is, number one, a new kind of store of value and may be more importantly a speculative object with more volatility than any other financial market. And, you know, for some people that's attractive including my son.

CHATTERLEY: Three years ago, he was (INAUDIBLE).

FERGUSON: Like $350 (ph) was the price. If I had listen to him I wouldn't have to run around New York City doing institute like, you know, I've been (INAUDIBLE).

CHATTERLEY: Does he still own it?

FERGUSON: I wish, he would say not nearly enough because don't think he landscape (ph) in the room to make a message something like three.

FU: Wow (INAUDIBLE). But on paper he's doing pretty well right now. He reminds me of this on a regular basis. I mean the correction interesting. I had one thing that I came to see last year was that there would a correction because it has a classic bubble quality to it.

All those ICOs that initial coin offering were plastic bubbles. On territory a lot of it almost certainly fraudulent but I must say, I decided that 10,000 was the entry point. So when it went below 10, this week, I'm afraid I became a buyer.

FU: Wow, for disclosure. Niall Ferguson, Bitcoin owner.

FERGUSON: Yes, only my son's advice.

CHATTERLEY: Wow. Now we have to see Niall Ferguson Author of "The Square and the Tower" is staying with us.

(BREAK)

FU: Now still with us, is Niall Ferguson, he's new book "The Square and the Tower" looks at tensions in Silicon Valley between hierarchies and networks. And of course, not just in Silicon Valley but in countries and societies around the world.

Niall, let's talk a little bit about Uber here because is this a network in a same way that Facebook is a network or Twitter is a network? Or is it just a very narrow business in which Travis Kalanick has been able to ride the Silicon Valley wave?

FERGUSON: It was definitely a network business and ride sharing (ph) was a classic example of what you could do with what people called society market, the goal was to establish just the kind of dominance that had been established by Facebook and social network, Google and search et cetera.

And I think what's important here. I've read the story that you just talked about. It's not just the missteps Travis Kalanick made personally. It's also the fact that, I think he personified a certain Silicon Valley arrogance that I use to characterize as resistance is futile.

The attitude was, we have this awesome app, there's no point standing in our way. We will take the world one city at the time. And I can remember talking. We've seen another about this saying, you know, what is going to be different in Berlin. It's going to be different in China.

And indeed I write in the book about why it was the ultimately Uber lost the battle in China to Didi, which is an amazing story. And a typical story of what is going on in the world today, because these race if you like for dominance of these two sided markets is a race that's been run not just by U.S. companies but also by Chinese companies.

By the way, not by European companies, very interesting that Europe hasn't produced really any technology giants. And I think this races to relatively early stage. It's not clear who will really be dominant for example in global online retail 10 years from now. And my hunch is it won't necessarily be Amazon.

If you go talk to the people at Alibaba, they'll say we have a better understanding of emerging markets and we're going to own not just china, we're going to own Eurasia, and then move on to Africa and Latin America and leave you guys the United States, that would be a really remarkable turn of events that it happened.

CHATTERLEY: Do point that Travis though seems to be making, would be seemingly making to you that there was a regulator that so far behind.

The technology innovation go so fast, that actually they've got a potential hit and move into all these different markets.

FERGUSON: Right.

CHATTERLEY: And not necessarily worry so much. At one point in the story he was on his knees calling saying, I'm so terrible. He then jump up to go back into that meeting and was that, we have a P.R. problem. That there's no cultural problem there, we have a P.R. problem. At what point is that relevant for such a huge network and so many networks around the world that we have.

FERGUSON: I think that's a very Silicon Valley response to a problem. And it's not yet that different from the way Facebook initially responded when people started to say, hey, you know, you played something of a destabilizing role in the 2016 election.

Mark Zuckerberg initial reaction was, the idea that fake news on Facebook had anything to do with this result is crazy. Well, of course, the tone quickly changed but at first the response is always, we have a P.R. problem, go fix the P.R., rather than recognizing. But sometimes the problems are very fundamental.

CHATTERLEY: So respond or break?

FERGUSON: I think there has to be a bigger response than we've seen so far. These companies have become enormously powerful with huge markets shares. I don't think there's ever going to be a successful breakup. I think antitrust won't work.

But I do think we need to think about the implications, particularly in the realm of our public sphere, of having a very small number of companies dominating online advertising, you know, Mike Bloomberg himself said just last year there has to be some liability for the content that these network platform produce.

I agree with that wholeheartedly. It's an anomaly that the biggest content publishers are being regulated as they just tech companies. And I think you're right. The regulators are behind as they are with Bitcoin, as they're with cryptocurrency.

But history tells us that no matter how rapidly a network grows, the regulators, the government eventually catches up.

CHATTERLEY: But the network itself has a backlash go with Didi Uber (INAUDIBLE). Where network itself then that was responds and try to politic change.

FERGUSON: And there is something about backlash for Facebook too, just beginning to make itself felt.

FU: Right. Niall Ferguson Author of "The Square and the Tower", thank you for that.

(BREAK)

CHATTERLEY: Still with us Niall Ferguson and just being that's going to be an interesting vote in Pennsylvania for Trump here.

FERGUSON: Absolutely, Pennsylvania a key state for him in 2016. It's a place where he'll be looking to mobilize those voters as he turn back in November.

FU: Why do you think his popularity is still so high? There's so much resilience there, even as we talk earlier about his missteps, for instance sounding off on Twitter, making these comments that don't help him, where he shoots himself in the foot.

FERGUSON: Well, somewhere around about a third, maybe for 35 percent and may be 40 percent of voters are very solidly pro Trump. And I don't think it's just his larger than life personality. There was content to Trump's campaign. Sometimes this is forgotten in all the discussion.

FU: But the content changes a lot.

FERGUSON: Yes, but the message when he ran was I'm going to do something about immigration, I'm going to do something about trade, free trade. I'm also going to tackle the perception that Washington is corrupt and it's a swamp.

And I think those votes were attracted by that message are prepared to cut Donald Trump an awful lot of slack as long as they feel that he is still roughly pointing in that direction and as long as they feel that he connects with them.

And I do think his ability to connect with people in Middle America, considering the man is a wealthy New York real estate developer by origin is amazing. But it's real. And I think that's the key, his ability to talk to them in the sometimes off-color language that they relate to.

So those people are not going to defect, and from the Republican establishment's point of view, they can't deserve Donald Trump. You can't give away a third of the electorate.

FU: Yes.

CHATTERLEY: Yes. The question is, can he do anything wrong in their eyes. We're going to come back to this conversation.

(BREAK)

CHATTERLEY: We're back with Niall Ferguson. The author of "The Square and the Tower". Trump in Davos, how's that going to g?

FERGUSON: It won't go that bad. I mean, they're going to talk to him with rough legs, are they? It's Davos, he's the president that Klaus Schwab will be polite. They'll be plenty of applause. I guess he'll give a speech somewhat like his Warsaw speech. And I'll be OK.

I mean, Davos hate Trump and what he stands for.

CHATTERLEY: He's antithesis (ph) of the Davos.

FERGUSON: Yes. I mean he basically hates some globalization and that's what they're about. On the other hand he's powerful. He's the President of the United States and Davos also like power. So I thin -- he'll get kind of polite somewhat frosty reception.

But I think the interesting thing about Davos is that it is the network of network. I mean that's where people go who live to network. And it's the very high end network. The question will be, what will go on behind the scene, I don't really care about the speeches and sessions. What's important at Davos is the meetings.

FU: Who's at piano bar at midnight?

FERGUSON: Correct. And I know suppose Trump will there. At lease his handlers where he want him to be at the piano bar at midnight. But may be interesting meetings going on back stage in those meetings rooms and some of the big hotels.

The interesting to see that any of the leaders, the European leaders for example Macron will be there. The French President Emmanuel Macron, the German Chancellor Angela Merkel. They going to meet with Trump. If anything going to get done, that's for me the interesting point.

FU: What's the most important meeting for him do you think?

FERGUSON: Well, I think that if you think back to the way Macron played him with that eternal handshake, the longest handshake in diplomatic history.

FU: We've already seen that.

FERGUSON: Well, the question really is can Macron help Trump in Europe. Trump is deeply unpopular in Europe even more unpopular than in Manhattan harder that is to believe. And yet, Trump is actually being winning on the key issue, which is being European contribution to NATO. He's kind of won that argument, they had to fold because he was right.

I sense there's a possibility that relationship with France can yield something for the United States and compensate for Trump's deep on popularity amongst European population.

CHATTERLEY: There some little bit of bromance there.

FERGUSON: Definitely.

CHATTERLEY: Niall Ferguson author of "The Square and the Tower", thank you so much.

[*]

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

NIALL FERGUSON, SENIOR FELLOW, HOOVER INSTITUTE, IS INTERVIEWED ON BB TV

JANUARY 18, 2018

SPEAKERS: NIALL FERGUSON, SENIOR FELLOW, HOOVER INSTITUTE

JULIA CHATTERLEY, BLOOMBERG NEWS

SCARLET FU, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] SCARLET FU, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: We want to bring in Niall Ferguson now. He's a Senior Fellow at the Hoover Institution at Stanford University, and a Senior Fellow at the Center for European state at Harvard. He is also the Author of the new book "The Square and the Tower. Networks empower from the Freemasons to Facebook.

Niall, thanks so much for joining us today.

NIALL FERGUSON, SENIOR FELLOW, HOOVER INSTITUTE: Great to be here.

FU: So we were just talking with Mike about President Trump and the looming government shutdown, if that happens. I want to start first with the presidency with you because in the past, you have called his presidency a comedy rather than a tragedy.

We've seen the administration scramble to perhaps a government shutdown, while at the same time saying may be a shutdown will be good. No matter what happens though, the base and his support is still there. Is it a wise move for the President right now to be pinning everything on the base staying with him as he touts the economy doing well and the stock market doing well, that can all go up in flames very quickly?

FERGUSON: It could. We all know that financial markets have a way of surprising that the bull market is forever. And there have been many people, my colleague at Harvard Martin Feldstein just this weekend in the general who've warned that a correction could come along and spoil that post of Donald Trumps argument.

But on the other hand if you look at that approval rating of his, it has not been taking off in the last few --

FU: From a little bit.

FERGUSON: From a historic a little bit. Remember he was the most unpopular President at the outset, since polling began. And he didn't get any more popular in his first year. But you begin to see the possible inflection point here as the economic good news just keeps on coming in. Plus it's a point that Trump is getting some wins on foreign policy, there aren't really anything like enough airtime.

I mean, he can change the policy in Iran and by the end of last year. Iran was in a state of upheaval. He took a much tougher line on North Korea. And now guess what, the North Korean's and South Korean's are making nice with one another.

So, one of the things that ordered by the Trump Presidencies is the way that he tend to shoot himself with that Twitter feed of his. And if he tweeted less and said fewer off the cuff races things that shocked so many peoples unjustly, we would be focusing more on the outcomes. We'd be focusing more on what's actually getting done.

And I think that would in fact reflect much better on him.

JULIA CHATTERLEY, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Do you think he's undermining he's own success?

FERGUSON: Well, I think the strategy is come up in raging liberal by being outrageous has one benefit. That is that seems to force Democrats to the left. And I think on sees (ph) this on the immigration issue. It's quite good from a Republicans strategic point of few, if the Democrats become more and more committed to sanctuary cities to the undocumented.

A lot of Republicans don't feel good about that at all. But my sense is that the cost and benefits of the President's populist outrage are kind of finally poised at this point. And I'm not sure he's necessary net better off with some of the most outrageous things that he said of late.

I think if he'd said much less over the last let say 12 months. And focus more on the achievements, he'd be riding higher in the polls.

CHATTERLEY: Do you think we've seen the loads as far as the politics concerns because as many aspects now already short-term and longer-term are playing to his favor, if we keep the tweeting aside?

FERGUSON: Right. I mean, one of the things I've tried to argue in The Square and the Tower is that we have a new kind of politics.

CHATTERLEY: Right.

FERGUSON: Which some of the still struggling to get ahead around is the public spear that's no longer dominated by network television, that's increasingly dominated by social media and the President has shown himself to have much better understanding not just the Twitter but the Facebook than his political rivals.

So one thing I did learn over two years of thinking and writing about Donald Trump is don't underestimate him and don't make the mistake of judging him by conventional measure. One thing I did recently was to just to run an experiment. I ask myself leaving aside personalities.

What presidency is this dislike? I mean this like the first year of Nixon and a lots of people have drawn that parallel, there's a lot of Democrats who would love this to be Watergate all over again is even the movie by Spielberg and go watch, you'd fantasize that.

You know, the Washington Post bringing down Donald Trump. It's not really like Nixon's first year at all, its much more like Bill Clinton first year. Go back and read woodward the agenda, change the names and you can have the version of what we've seen in the last year.

(CROSSTALK)

CHATTERLEY: We're going to talk more about (INAUDIBLE) Niall Ferguson, Author of "The Square and the Tower is staying with us.

(BREAK)

CHATTERLEY: We're back with Niall Ferguson. He is author of the new book "The Square and the Tower", Networks Empower from the Freemasons to Facebook. So we were just talking before about the sort of fundamental basis of this book and what it means and actually where Donald Trump sits in between the interplay between hierarchies in history and social network.

And how they've evolved overtime, he is someone who harness in a unique way like thinking political terms at least at that point in time, the power of social network and what that mean for democracy.

.FERGUSON: Well, in someway in the Brexit referendum was like the over the chart of the main show in 2016 because the leave campaign used Facebook as an advertising tool and just the way of the Trump campaign did.

But this book is about showing how social networks have always been there. It's not like Marks (ph) of Caberg (ph) invented them. All that Facebook did was to make them bigger and faster than they ever were before. But throughout history there have been periods when a new networks have come along and disrupted established hierarchies, those big tower of power that usually rule.

And my favorite example is from 500 years ago when the printing press completely disrupted European politics, causes the reformation Martin Luther without the printing press would just been birth at the state like hierarchy (ph). And we've never averted him.

CHATTERLEY: When you got the day off on Monday.

FERGUSON: It's true. So that certain that's another Martin Luther, that Martin the King introvertly and so had a social network, in the civil rights wouldn't have work if they haven't been this network of churches in the South that had the people organized and should cancel their commitment when it came to often very hazardous demonstration.

Social networks all that you don't need the internet to have them. All we've done is making them bigger and faster and I think more powerful than they've been certainly anytime in the last 400 or 300 years.

FU: And easier to corrupt as well, because of the platform.

FERGUSON: Right, this is the problem that makes it different from the age of printing press. There wasn't one person who owned over printing press is in 16th or 17th century Europe whereas social networks today are very concentrated and their ownership.

And this point of view, it's kind of extraordinary, these quasi-monopolies that have emerged online and seach, you've got Google retail, you've got Amazon, and of course in social media we've got Facebook.

This is extraordinary power. Facebook is the biggest content publisher in all of history. Zuckerberg is more powerful than William Randolph Hearst or Rupert Murdoch, any previous proprietor of the media organization.

And yet, Facebook is regulated as if it's a tech platform, not a content publisher. And that seem to me an extraordinary anomaly considering that 45 percent of Americans are getting their news from Facebook.

FU: Facebook is also reluctant to take on mental (ph) of assuming responsibility, should they?

CHATTERLEY: Also now.

FERGUSON: Well, they're indeed. And it's one of the key arguments that I think will play out in the coming years. Is it a content publisher? If it is, should it be liable for all the content that appears and the content, his vast in his content (ph).

I mean every now and then they'll say that they're hiring 10,000 people to bet the content. I mean come on the sheer scale of the content that is if you're Facebook he's going to require many, many more than 10,000 fact checkers.

I think this us a big issue. A lot of discussion on the big tech companies recently has been about anti-trust. I think that is a complete red herring. These are natural monopolies, you couldn't break them up. It's not going to happen. And the law, I don't think would support antitrust actions against these companies.

But I think the exemptions from liability for content that we're establishing mid 1990's when Facebook didn't even exist, those look like a vulnerability and I would just surprise if legislators and regulators begun to ask questions about that in the coming months

CHATTERLEY: What about for somebody like Amazon and the power that they continue to accrue or Google for that matter? Like who disrupts the ultimate disruptive that they've been in such a small space of time.

FERGUSON: Well, if I were Jeff Bezos, I wish I were. But I would be worried much more about my rivals in Asia. I'd be looking at Alibaba, I'd be looking at Jack Ma and I'd be thinking, you know, I thought I was going to own the rest of world and you would just of China.

I begin to wonder and I just was Hang Joe (ph) looking at what's going on. Alibaba could it be that the big Chinese tech companies are about to make a push for market share outside of China, and we might find the U.S. companies beginning to lose that. That would be my worry at Amazon.

FU: Niall Ferguson, Author of "The Square and the Tower" is going to stay with us.

(BREAK)

CHATTERLEY: Let's talk a bit more now about Bitcoin. We're back with Niall Ferguson. He says Bitcoin mega pot but the revolution will go on.

FERGUSON: Well, I said that when it was around about I think 1900 and it did go drop (ph). I have to tell about the story --

FU: You should be trading.

FERGUSON: Well, I don't know. The first thing should be trading is my son. So when he's 15th, it's now 18th now some back he said to me "Dad, you really should buy Bitcoin." And pompously I Professor Ferguson says "Young man, what do you know about financial history, this can never work. And I would call Jamie Dimon I almost said tulips (ph).

Well, I kind of learn the hard way. He was right. And I can got -- that caught up last year and began to really think about this. And we're amidst of an Amazing financial revolution which isn't just about Bitcoin. It's about Blockchain generally and what Blockchain can do.

I think a lot of people have got, you got confused by the term cryptocurrency. And because I'm not sure that we're going to produce a new form of money this way. But we have produced, what Bitcoin has produced is, number one, a new kind of store of value and may be more importantly a speculative object with more volatility than any other financial market. And, you know, for some people that's attractive including my son.

CHATTERLEY: Three years ago, he was (INAUDIBLE).

FERGUSON: Like $350 (ph) was the price. If I had listen to him I wouldn't have to run around New York City doing institute like, you know, I've been (INAUDIBLE).

CHATTERLEY: Does he still own it?

FERGUSON: I wish, he would say not nearly enough because don't think he landscape (ph) in the room to make a message something like three.

FU: Wow (INAUDIBLE). But on paper he's doing pretty well right now. He reminds me of this on a regular basis. I mean the correction interesting. I had one thing that I came to see last year was that there would a correction because it has a classic bubble quality to it.

All those ICOs that initial coin offering were plastic bubbles. On territory a lot of it almost certainly fraudulent but I must say, I decided that 10,000 was the entry point. So when it went below 10, this week, I'm afraid I became a buyer.

FU: Wow, for disclosure. Niall Ferguson, Bitcoin owner.

FERGUSON: Yes, only my son's advice.

CHATTERLEY: Wow. Now we have to see Niall Ferguson Author of "The Square and the Tower" is staying with us.

FU: Now still with us, is Niall Ferguson, he's new book "The Square and the Tower" looks at tensions in Silicon Valley between hierarchies and networks. And of course, not just in Silicon Valley but in countries and societies around the world.

Niall, let's talk a little bit about Uber here because is this a network in a same way that Facebook is a network or Twitter is a network? Or is it just a very narrow business in which Travis Kalanick has been able to ride the Silicon Valley wave?

FERGUSON: It was definitely a network business and ride sharing (ph) was a classic example of what you could do with what people called society market, the goal was to establish just the kind of dominance that had been established by Facebook and social network, Google and search et cetera.

And I think what's important here. I've read the story that you just talked about. It's not just the missteps Travis Kalanick made personally. It's also the fact that, I think he personified a certain Silicon Valley arrogance that I use to characterize as resistance is futile.

The attitude was, we have this awesome app, there's no point standing in our way. We will take the world one city at the time. And I can remember talking. We've seen another about this saying, you know, what is going to be different in Berlin. It's going to be different in China.

FERGUSON: Definitely.

JANUARY 18, 2018

JULIA CHATTERLEY, BLOOMBERG NEWS

SCARLET FU, BLOOMBERG NEWS

He's a Senior Fellow at the Hoover Institution at Stanford University, and a Senior Fellow at the Center for European state at Harvard. He is also the Author of the new book "The Square and the Tower. Networks empower from the Freemasons to Facebook.

Niall, thanks so much for joining us today.

FU: So we were just talking with Mike about President Trump and the looming government shutdown, if that happens. I want to start first with the presidency with you because in the past, you have called his presidency a comedy rather than a tragedy.

But on the other hand if you look at that approval rating of his, it has not been taking off in the last few --

FU: From a little bit.

FERGUSON: From a historic a little bit. Remember he was the most unpopular President at the outset, since polling began. And he didn't get any more popular in his first year. But you begin to see the possible inflection point here as the economic good news just keeps on coming in. Plus it's a point that Trump is getting some wins on foreign policy, there aren't really anything like enough airtime.

I mean, he can change the policy in Iran and by the end of last year. Iran was in a state of upheaval. He took a much tougher line on North Korea. And now guess what, the North Korean's and South Korean's are making nice with one another.

So, one of the things that ordered by the Trump Presidencies is the way that he tend to shoot himself with that Twitter feed of his. And if he tweeted less and said fewer off the cuff races things that shocked so many peoples unjustly, we would be focusing more on the outcomes. We'd be focusing more on what's actually getting done.

And I think that would in fact reflect much better on him.

And I think on sees (ph) this on the immigration issue. It's quite good from a Republicans strategic point of few, if the Democrats become more and more committed to sanctuary cities to the undocumented.

A lot of Republicans don't feel good about that at all. But my sense is that the cost and benefits of the President's populist outrage are kind of finally poised at this point. And I'm not sure he's necessary net better off with some of the most outrageous things that he said of late.

I think if he'd said much less over the last let say 12 months. And focus more on the achievements, he'd be riding higher in the polls.

You know, the Washington Post bringing down Donald Trump. It's not really like Nixon's first year at all, its much more like Bill Clinton first year. Go back and read woodward the agenda, change the names and you can have the version of what we've seen in the last year.

.FERGUSON: Well, in someway in the Brexit referendum was like the over the chart of the main show in 2016 because the leave campaign used Facebook as an advertising tool and just the way of the Trump campaign did.

FERGUSON: It was definitely a network business and ride sharing (ph) was a classic example of what you could do with what people called society market, the goal was to establish just the kind of dominance that had been established by Facebook and social network, Google and search et cetera.

And I think what's important here. I've read the story that you just talked about. It's not just the missteps Travis Kalanick made personally. It's also the fact that, I think he personified a certain Silicon Valley arrogance that I use to characterize as resistance is futile.

The attitude was, we have this awesome app, there's no point standing in our way. We will take the world one city at the time. And I can remember talking. We've seen another about this saying, you know, what is going to be different in Berlin. It's going to be different in China.

And indeed I write in the book about why it was the ultimately Uber lost the battle in China to Didi, which is an amazing story. And a typical story of what is going on in the world today, because these race if you like for dominance of these two sided markets is a race that's been run not just by U.S. companies but also by Chinese companies.

By the way, not by European companies, very interesting that Europe hasn't produced really any technology giants. And I think this races to relatively early stage. It's not clear who will really be dominant for example in global online retail 10 years from now. And my hunch is it won't necessarily be Amazon.

If you go talk to the people at Alibaba, they'll say we have a better understanding of emerging markets and we're going to own not just china, we're going to own Eurasia, and then move on to Africa and Latin America and leave you guys the United States, that would be a really remarkable turn of events that it happened.

CHATTERLEY: Do point that Travis though seems to be making, would be seemingly making to you that there was a regulator that so far behind.

The technology innovation go so fast, that actually they've got a potential hit and move into all these different markets.

FERGUSON: Right.

CHATTERLEY: And not necessarily worry so much. At one point in the story he was on his knees calling saying, I'm so terrible. He then jump up to go back into that meeting and was that, we have a P.R. problem. That there's no cultural problem there, we have a P.R. problem. At what point is that relevant for such a huge network and so many networks around the world that we have.

FERGUSON: I think that's a very Silicon Valley response to a problem. And it's not yet that different from the way Facebook initially responded when people started to say, hey, you know, you played something of a destabilizing role in the 2016 election.

Mark Zuckerberg initial reaction was, the idea that fake news on Facebook had anything to do with this result is crazy. Well, of course, the tone quickly changed but at first the response is always, we have a P.R. problem, go fix the P.R., rather than recognizing. But sometimes the problems are very fundamental.

CHATTERLEY: So respond or break?

FERGUSON: I think there has to be a bigger response than we've seen so far. These companies have become enormously powerful with huge markets shares. I don't think there's ever going to be a successful breakup. I think antitrust won't work.

But I do think we need to think about the implications, particularly in the realm of our public sphere, of having a very small number of companies dominating online advertising, you know, Mike Bloomberg himself said just last year there has to be some liability for the content that these network platform produce.

I agree with that wholeheartedly. It's an anomaly that the biggest content publishers are being regulated as they just tech companies. And I think you're right. The regulators are behind as they are with Bitcoin, as they're with cryptocurrency.

But history tells us that no matter how rapidly a network grows, the regulators, the government eventually catches up.

CHATTERLEY: But the network itself has a backlash go with Didi Uber (INAUDIBLE). Where network itself then that was responds and try to politic change.

FERGUSON: And there is something about backlash for Facebook too, just beginning to make itself felt.

FU: Right. Niall Ferguson Author of "The Square and the Tower", thank you for that.

(BREAK)

CHATTERLEY: Still with us Niall Ferguson and just being that's going to be an interesting vote in Pennsylvania for Trump here.

FERGUSON: Absolutely, Pennsylvania a key state for him in 2016. It's a place where he'll be looking to mobilize those voters as he turn back in November.

FU: Why do you think his popularity is still so high? There's so much resilience there, even as we talk earlier about his missteps, for instance sounding off on Twitter, making these comments that don't help him, where he shoots himself in the foot.

FERGUSON: Well, somewhere around about a third, maybe for 35 percent and may be 40 percent of voters are very solidly pro Trump. And I don't think it's just his larger than life personality. There was content to Trump's campaign. Sometimes this is forgotten in all the discussion.

FU: But the content changes a lot.

FERGUSON: Yes, but the message when he ran was I'm going to do something about immigration, I'm going to do something about trade, free trade. I'm also going to tackle the perception that Washington is corrupt and it's a swamp.

And I think those votes were attracted by that message are prepared to cut Donald Trump an awful lot of slack as long as they feel that he is still roughly pointing in that direction and as long as they feel that he connects with them.

And I do think his ability to connect with people in Middle America, considering the man is a wealthy New York real estate developer by origin is amazing. But it's real. And I think that's the key, his ability to talk to them in the sometimes off-color language that they relate to.

So those people are not going to defect, and from the Republican establishment's point of view, they can't deserve Donald Trump. You can't give away a third of the electorate.

FU: Yes.

CHATTERLEY: Yes. The question is, can he do anything wrong in their eyes. We're going to come back to this conversation.

(BREAK)

CHATTERLEY: We're back with Niall Ferguson. The author of "The Square and the Tower". Trump in Davos, how's that going to g?

FERGUSON: It won't go that bad. I mean, they're going to talk to him with rough legs, are they? It's Davos, he's the president that Klaus Schwab will be polite. They'll be plenty of applause. I guess he'll give a speech somewhat like his Warsaw speech. And I'll be OK.

I mean, Davos hate Trump and what he stands for.

CHATTERLEY: He's antithesis (ph) of the Davos.

FERGUSON: Yes. I mean he basically hates some globalization and that's what they're about. On the other hand he's powerful. He's the President of the United States and Davos also like power. So I thin -- he'll get kind of polite somewhat frosty reception.

But I think the interesting thing about Davos is that it is the network of network. I mean that's where people go who live to network. And it's the very high end network. The question will be, what will go on behind the scene, I don't really care about the speeches and sessions. What's important at Davos is the meetings.

FU: Who's at piano bar at midnight?

FERGUSON: Correct. And I know suppose Trump will there. At lease his handlers where he want him to be at the piano bar at midnight. But may be interesting meetings going on back stage in those meetings rooms and some of the big hotels.

The interesting to see that any of the leaders, the European leaders for example Macron will be there. The French President Emmanuel Macron, the German Chancellor Angela Merkel. They going to meet with Trump. If anything going to get done, that's for me the interesting point.

FU: What's the most important meeting for him do you think?

FERGUSON: Well, I think that if you think back to the way Macron played him with that eternal handshake, the longest handshake in diplomatic history.

FU: We've already seen that.

FERGUSON: Well, the question really is can Macron help Trump in Europe. Trump is deeply unpopular in Europe even more unpopular than in Manhattan harder that is to believe. And yet, Trump is actually being winning on the key issue, which is being European contribution to NATO. He's kind of won that argument, they had to fold because he was right.

I sense there's a possibility that relationship with France can yield something for the United States and compensate for Trump's deep on popularity amongst European population.

CHATTERLEY: There some little bit of bromance there.

FERGUSON: Definitely.

CHATTERLEY: Niall Ferguson author of "The Square and the Tower", thank you so much.

[*]

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***
