urn:contentItem:59XV-GNR1-JD2T-F0DM-00000-00Nicholas Thompson, Robert Profusek2013-11-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:25ZLexisNexisNicholas Thompson, Robert Profusek

NICHOLAS THOMPSON, BLOOMBERG CONTRIBUTING EDITOR, & ROBERT PROFUSEK, GLOBAL HEAD OF MERGERS AND ACQUISITIONS, JONES DAY, ARE INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG SURVEILLANCE

NOVEMBER 26, 2013

SPEAKERS: ROBERT PROFUSEK, GLOBAL HEAD OF MERGERS AND ACQUISITIONS, JONES DAY

NICHOLAS THOMPSON, BLOOMBERG CONTRIBUTING EDITOR

TOM KEENE, BLOOMBERG NEWS

CRISTINA ALESCI, BLOOMBERG NEWS

SCARLET FU, BLOOMBERG NEWS

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

TOM KEENE, BLOOMBERG NEWS: Robert Profusek is Global Head of Mergers and Acquisitions. He is a partner at Jones Day, a global law firm. And they represent 502 of the Fortune 500. Nick Thompson is Bloomberg Contributing Editor and with The New Yorker Magazine as well. Nick, what have you learned about Iran? I think The New Yorker has done great work on this, but what is distinctive that we need to know since our Saturday evening?

NICHOLAS THOMPSON, BLOOMBERG CONTRIBUTING EDITOR: The most distinctive thing to know is that we actually finally have a deal that we have diplomacy that seems to be working because sanctions were so effective. We're seen that putting strong pressure and then having negotiations, as we saw in Syria, now as we see in Iran, turns out to be a good mix. The American political system right now may actually be a very good political system for making deals because you have a president who wants to negotiate, and you have a Congress and you also have a history that indicates a willingness to go to war.

KEENE: Bob Profusek, we're going to talk about China here in a bit on M&A, but let's talk about the basic idea of 2013. What happened? Do we blame the lawyers that there were no deals?

ROBERT PROFUSEK, GLOBAL HEAD OF MERGERS AND ACQUISITIONS, JONES DAY: Well it depends on how you look at it. There were plenty of deals, not that many big mega deals, but some. There you mentioned -

KEENE: You guys are busy.

PROFUSEK: Yes. It's been a very good year.

KEENE: Your associates are fed. They're well fed.

PROFUSEK: And they are working on Thanksgiving.

CRISTINA ALESCI, BLOOMBERG NEWS: Well the lawyers are always busy.

PROFUSEK: Well -

KEENE: Do you know major -

ALESCI: The lawyers are always busy. The lawyers are doing the work and [they said] the bankers are the ones that want more, more, more, more.

KEENE: I totally agree with you. Major law firms have like eight Christmas parties.

ALESCI: Yes.

KEENE: That's what I know.

SCARLET FU, BLOOMBERG NEWS: Has that changed since -

ALESCI: Why? Did you crash all of them?

KEENE: It's just the way it is. But you guys have been busy, right?

PROFUSEK: Yes. We've been busy because it's been - there have been some big deals. There were Verizon we worked on.

FU: A lot in the telecom.

PROFUSEK: And Tokyo Electron. We're doing plenty of them, but they've been smaller. They've been sort of beneath the front page headlines size.

KEENE: Well we've got a lot to talk about this hour, particularly on China. This is an emotional issue as well.

(BREAK)

KEENE: Let's bring in Robert Profusek from Jones Day. Leadership is about a path, isn't it? This is one of the toughest things for companies to do.

PROFUSEK: Sure, and -

KEENE: Set up a leadership path.

PROFUSEK: And it can - and it's very difficult. And sometimes there's some breakage, as it was mentioned that when you set up an internal system there are winners and losers.

KEENE: Is there a best practice here that you see each and every day for corporations?

PROFUSEK: There's no question that the best practice is to hire from within. You know what you're getting when you go through external search.

ALESCI: Hire from within even though they've got to do better on the line and -

PROFUSEK: Yes. They've got to do better.

ALESCI: - decided basically very little experience on that front.

PROFUSEK: Yes. And that's an important point. When you got to make a shift in direction maybe there's a good argument for getting somebody from the outside, but the search process is inherently to some degree superficial. And I'm on a lot of, a couple of boards. You have a two hour -

FU: It's to make sure that you don't miss anything.

PROFUSEK: Yes. You have a two-hour interview. You do all the checking. Everybody says they're great.

KEENE: Are you representing Microsoft at this time? I just want to be -

PROFUSEK: No.

KEENE: Okay. You're not representing Microsoft. There's the ultimate search going on right now. You say you need an internal candidate, but that I suggest would be a different story with Alan Mulally front and center.

PROFUSEK: Well when you've got to make - when you need to make a strategic move that argues, as was just mentioned for maybe taking somebody with a different perspective. I'm not sure Walmart needs to make some sort of U- turn or even veer off the [front].

KEENE: I agree you're going to do.

ALESCI: Well one major question is the fact that McMillon has actually got a lot of international experience or some international experience. So that's raised some questions about whether or not there's going to be more of a focus given the fact that they really fumbled the ball on that front.

FU: Well there is some talk that perhaps he will focus more and internationally. David Strasser of Janney Montgomery Scott says he doesn't believe that he'll ignore the United States because the U.S. has actually quite well under Bill Simon. Actually David Strasser says that the biggest benefit that McMillon brings with him, his best strength, is that he's a great communicator. And that's important because this is a company with 2.2 million employees.

KEENE: It's unreal how big it is.

FU: They do business with so many vendors, with so many countries. And of course the investment community that is the Walmart CEO's job to speak to its different constituents.

KEENE: Let me bring in Michael Eckstein's quote from Credit Suisse. I spoke to him yesterday. They're terrific analysts on big box retail. Of course they go into that crucial season. We view McMillon as pragmatic and realistic. We think he will continue the legacy of focus on compliance and the core values of the company. And the idea is just simply passing the torch.

And here's more on it. We do believe that he will continue to hold the international division to very standards.

FU: He also suggested there might be possible divestitures from Walmart as well, which a lot of people have called for as a way to further unlock shareholder value as the parlance of the time.

ALESCI: More deals, more deals.

FU: More deals for Bob Profusek.

KEENE: It's going to be fascinating, just fascinating to see what Walmart does here. Again I go back to share price and that Mr. Duke delivered the goods, whatever the case with nominal GDP and domestic challenges.

ALESCI: He did, so certainly played a [credit] for that.

FU: Yes. So Bill Simon did do quite a bit. And Mike Duke also people are saying there's a lot of question marks over whether he was pushed out. No. The guy was getting ready to retire. Sure he had the shortest tenure of any Walmart CEO, but he did do more than just hold the ship together. He did get Walmart through a very tough period going through the financial crisis and recovery.

KEENE: Right, Nick Thompson with us as well from The New Yorker. You have written definitely on your grandfather, Paul Nitze, and the game theory if you will of war. What can leadership in corporations learn from your foreign affairs world? What can they learn from the complexity of diplomacy?

THOMPSON: Well the complexity of diplomacy is quite different from corporations because you're switching out the players every four years. And so you have a very limited time frame in which you have to negotiate. So some of the ways are different, but I think you do - you do have to very much plan for worst case scenarios. I think that's actually one thing that you can learn when you're planning an internal succession versus external succession. If you bring in from somebody from the outside you're entering a more high-risk environment than if you bring internally.

KEENE: And that learning curve, which is - anybody from the outside has a massive learning curve.

THOMPSON: Massive learning curve, which you actually see in politics where people come in and they tend to make a whole lot of mistakes in the beginning as they try to figure out how things -

KEENE: Is the president still in the learning curve? I got make some news here this morning. Help me, Nick.

THOMPSON: It's funny. The president, he came in and everybody said he has no experience and it's going to be very hard. And then he was very successful, at least legislatively the first couple years. Now that he certainly knows how to be president, there's not an experience question, he's had a really rough time.

KEENE: It's been [rough].

THOMPSON: Throw that theory out the window.

06:17:03

(BREAK)

06:23:41

KEENE: Robert Profusek with us with Jones Day. Bob, you look at the new activism. Bill Ackman was in our offices supporting a charity yesterday with our Erik Schatzker. Is Bill Ackman good for the market?

PROFUSEK: Well it depends on what length of period here, Tom, you're looking at. Part of activism is just is to accelerate the future to the present.

KEENE: And it's always been there.

PROFUSEK: And it's always been there. We called them back in the '80s before you were probably out of high school we called them raiders. It was a different word, but activism has been there. What's different about today is there's a huge amount of capital committed to it. If you're a CalPERS, some nice fund, -

FU: Yes. The fund simply management (inaudible).

PROFUSEK: - you've got to -

ALESCI: But this isn't just about corporate raiders or -

PROFUSEK: No.

ALESCI: - what you would call corporate raiders. This is long-term investors that are pressing for change. These are people who have nothing to do with the corporate raiders. They're actually supporting the Bill Ackman's and the Icahn's of the world behind the scenes. And here's the money that you actually (inaudible).

PROFUSEK: Well what they're - what they're saying is go back to whether it's good for employees then. What that means is cut back on your R&D now, but this is a message in Wall Street generally, which is I need more cash right now because I'm in this lower yield environment, don't want to invest. Don't do R&D. Don't buy that little thing. Give me the money.

KEENE: I critically look at the time frame of the activist. Who is supporting them besides themselves? It's almost a narcissistic event. Who's supporting them?

PROFUSEK: Well there's plenty of support in the institutional investor community. There's - it's with the shift in the corporate governance paradigm in general. You've got something called the ISS. We've got all these other forces. They're all for value today.

KEENE: Bob Profusek with us with Jones Day.

(BREAK)

KEENE: Bob, it's front and center here. There was a [Unical] blowup a couple years ago back and forth with Canada and such. Is there a new-new as we go into 2014 with Chinese acquisition of our assets?

PROFUSEK: Yes. I think it's - Smithfield was important psychologically. For a little bit everybody said, okay, maybe this is a national security issues, something called Cfius is the way it operates down in Washington, but Smithfield made sausage, and bacon and stuff like that. And it was sort of hard to argue it was a national security item, but it was big. It was $2.8 billion. And that was a little bit of a breakthrough, especially in the mind of the Chinese businessperson, saying that we can do this stuff.

KEENE: Is the distinction here a majority ownership, or are they more shrewd to take modest minority ownerships across a broad swath of companies, almost like a sovereign wealth fund?

PROFUSEK: Oh they're doing a lot of that.

KEENE: Yes.

PROFUSEK: When the - as of September 30 they had the [poor] side there was $12 billion of investment from China into the U.S. this year. That's way understated because what it doesn't include is things like investments in private equity firms, investments in deals that private equity firms put together that are ten - they take a ten percent position.

ALESCI: What?

KEENE: Are they visible under five percent? If they buy three percent of IBM or Walmart, do people -

PROFUSEK: No, no, not if it's a passive investment.

KEENE: It's invisible.

PROFUSEK: Yes, totally invisible.

KEENE: Yes.

PROFUSEK: And I would suggest to you that $12 billion number, which still is really big that five years ago it was $300 million, something like that.

ALESCI: What's the biggest challenge to actually getting a deal done because we know that the government would rather see the investment stay in the country and not export the capital to the U.S.

PROFUSEK: Actually the Chinese are trying to export their capital to the U.S. One of the things, law firms like mine we rushed over to China, and I think most professional services firms on the assumption that capital was going to China. That was totally wrong. It's coming.

KEENE: What have you learned in the last 24 months with Jones Day's work in China? What is the message you would have to Americans about business practices that you see in China?

PROFUSEK: It's well capital is coming the other way, and you've got to do your homework. You can't just come here and say we like to do this. You've got to - it's got to do prep work. The Smithfield deal was not prewired. You can't do that in this country.

FU: No.

PROFUSEK: But it was preplanned, pre thought out, both IR, government relations, everything else. And you can get it done. Now if you're - if a Chinese company is trying to buy a big tech company it gets all different. A year ago, -

FU: Yes.

PROFUSEK: - I don't know if you remember this Hawker Beechcraft, this situation made - they made airplanes. Now they're for commercial application, but what's the difference?

FU: They were more a national security concern.

PROFUSEK: Right, right, so of course.

FU: But the Chinese companies have gotten a lot more adept in navigating the political and regulatory waters.

PROFUSEK: Yes, absolutely.

FU: My question to you -

PROFUSEK: But the one thing that still is a little difficult in China is that the U.S. is a cacophonous place. And when Senator Schumer says, I don't like this, the Chinese businessperson says, wait a minute, and doesn't realize that that's just the way it is here that where we talk. In China if somebody like him said something it would over.

FU: Different, and different environment certainly. What's different between Chinese companies coming in and buying U.S. companies versus what Japanese companies did in the late '80s?

PROFUSEK: I - and from my point of view there is no difference really. Now there's more state -

FU: So it's all going to end in tears.

PROFUSEK: There's more state - I don't think so. There's more state money. And well one thing is don't forget China is sitting on a ton of treasuries. Would you rather be in treasuries or start putting and some of it -

KEENE: Okay. I'll go with that incentive, but I think the core issue of our viewers and listeners across America is who is investing in Smithfield? Is it a direct conduit from Beijing and the federal government? Or is it actually a freestanding company in China?

PROFUSEK: It's - oh no, freestanding yes.

KEENE: You buy the idea it's a freestanding company.

PROFUSEK: And it's a freestanding company, but let's not kid ourselves. It's a controlled economy. Someone has to say that's an okay thing to do.

KEENE: You don't think Beijing is rubberstamping some freestanding company's purchase of a pork maker and a sausage maker in America?

PROFUSEK: I think they're looking at it before it's done. State-owned companies are state-owned companies.

KEENE: Okay, interesting.

PROFUSEK: The state has a role.

FU: Well, Bob Profusek -

KEENE: Bob Profusek, fascinating, fascinating.

FU: Yes. Stay with us. We're going to have more on this, but we want to also pivot to another topic here. Elon Musk's SpaceX postponed the scheduled launch of its Falcon 9 spacecraft last night. The rocket was less than four minutes from liftoff at Cape Canaveral when the countdown was halted. Musk says there was a problem with the Falcon's liquid oxygen tank. The launch has been rescheduled for Thursday.

A little more than a year ago SpaceX completed the first regular cargo mission in commercial space flight. This mission will carry a communications satellite into orbit. So SpaceX couldn't get it done, and all this talk about how private companies are in a better position than the government to move forward.

KEENE: Right. Nick Thompson, Elon Musk has been a huge 2013 story. You've covered this. You've pondered it. You looked at it. What's your report card on Mr. Musk?

THOMPSON: And this is actually this stutter in the launch is sort of indicative of his year. He's an extraordinary year of success after success, but every time there's a string of success there's some setback. There's a fire at a Tesla factory. There's something that goes wrong with Tesla. There's something that goes wrong with SpaceX, but basically he's had the most interesting, most successful year (inaudible).

KEENE: It's amazing to see. And I've been a critic at times in writing for Bloomberg Businessweek, but the fact is this guy has jumpstarted innovation. He seems to be impervious to criticism.

THOMPSON: He's impervious to criticism. He's jumpstarting innovation. And he hasn't stopped dreaming big. He's going to build us a hyper loop that gets us to travel across (inaudible).

KEENE: Well that's what he says he's going to do, but what do you - what would you -

THOMPSON: Would you believe that of anybody else? No. You'd laugh it out of the room.

KEENE: What is your - what - that's true. What is your prescription for 2014 for Elon Musk?

THOMPSON: For Elon Musk he's probably going to start - we'll find (a) Tesla. Ideally for him Tesla will actually really start to make more inroads. We'll have a string of success, buy more and more cars and better and better. SpaceX will continue.

ALESCI: Do you think that it will grow into its tough Tesla specifically grow into its valuation, because we've seen the stock come up quite a bit.

THOMPSON: I'm not sure if it can grow into its valuation. I was just saying it should grow massively, not grow into its valuation. Let's not talk crazy here.

ALESCI: So you think it's overpriced then.

THOMPSON: Well Tesla there's a lot of promise. There are a lot of dreams built into Tesla, but there's also been a lot of success at Tesla. I think we'll see with Elon Musk the question is whether he'll get Ford to buy his current companies and he'll end up starting a fourth or fifth, and eventually whether those deals start to have an effect on them.

KEENE: Well Nick Thompson with us from The New Yorker, some interesting perspect - I'm fascinated by the year Mr. Musk has had.

FU: Yes. He's on the covers of all these different magazines. I'm seeing him left and right.

ALESCI: He's just like an interesting guy, right? He's a - he has the greatest ideas.

KEENE: What's the Dos Equis, he's had the world's most -

ALESCI: Most interesting man. I don't know if you can use him for that.

THOMPSON: So weird, and there are so many bizarre things about him, right? He's a man who has lots of children because he wants to improve the overall intelligence of the human race he said. He's a quirky guy.

FU: Yes.

KEENE: And I did that theory.

THOMPSON: That's all so good.

ALESCI: But that's part of his whole -

FU: For the new era.

ALESCI: Like that's just part of his whole character. It's the one that he's put out in public.

THOMPSON: Yes. And it seems genuine and real.

06:38:00

(BREAK)

06:43:16

KEENE: Nicholas Thompson with us with The New Yorker and Bloomberg adviser as well. Nick, this speaks so much of that phrase Eurosclerosis. We clear markets. We go back to Friedrich Hayek, 1945.

THOMPSON: Right.

KEENE: We do it. We clear markets. It's ugly, but we do it and they don't. Do you see any hope that Europe can become more malleable, more supple?

THOMPSON: You would actually you would hope so, but and there are so many cultural differences. There are language differences. They've tried to break us down. We've a pretty sclerotic political system right now that makes it hard to act. You saw that in our response to what happened in 2008. We responded very slowly, responded inefficiently, but we did actually respond. And that's a large reason why that chart heads up in the top.

KEENE: Yes.

THOMPSON: Europe has a much, much, much tougher time, but it's also the different kinds of responses. We chose more of a stimulus. They chose more of an austerity. A lot of people would make the argument that that's part of what's causing this [crisis].

KEENE: Yes. It's a huge question I think for next year, can Europe really get their act together now that the crisis is over.

(BREAK)

ALESCI: But I'm curious to get our guest host's opinion on this, Bob Profusek from Jones Day. What do you think went wrong or right at Sony in terms of the way Dan Loeb handled it?

PROFUSEK: Well I'd say Dan Loeb handled it about the best you can with a company like Sony. There was no question that he wasn't going to push around the company. This isn't some U.S. company where the boards are going to get weak kneed. And they didn't do what he said, which is separate the entertainment business, but the company's doing something, talking about it just right now that maybe -

ALESCI: Do you think the company would have done something if it were not for Loeb in there agitating?

PROFUSEK: And that's the question. And I guess my guess would be not really.

ALESCI: So in this case maybe an activist was basically -

PROFUSEK: Yes. And Japan's different. Companies are different. They're - there's the interlocking ownership and it's not like it is here where it's, again cacophony in the marketplace.

FU: Well we'll continue to monitor this one because it will play out certainly in the next couple of months. We want to switch topics here because the president's deadline of November 30th is to fix the healthcare.gov website is fast approaching. There are also fresh doubts over whether the site, which has been dogged by glitches will be fully functional by then. Can the Obama Administration take another hit from this beleaguered rollout?

And joining us now is our guest host for the hour, Bloomberg Contributing Editor Nick Thompson. So, Nick, November 30th is supposed to be the deadline, but Kathleen Sebelius, the Secretary of Health and Human and Services, has managed expectations lower, saying it's still going to be a work in progress beyond this date. And now the White House says - said that the website will work for the vast majority of users by the state. The problem seems to be the White House doesn't understand process is product. This process is what people are going to remember.

THOMPSON: Yes. And that is absolutely true, but I do think they're making the right move. Clearly even if they fixed everything they've identified by November 30th there are still going to be lots of terrible things that happen because of the press that's come beforehand. There's going to be lots of negative press on everything that happens, every idea that gets hacked or something like that. So they do absolutely have to manage expectations. I think they've done a pretty good job of saying it's not going to work perfectly. It's scheduled for a Saturday so there won't be too much attention. And it - they actually in the last 48 hours have started sounding a lot more optimistic than before.

FU: Okay.

THOMPSON: So maybe there's something we don't know.

FU: Maybe, maybe. We'll see how that goes, but how does this compare with say the live, a performance of an e-commerce website that goes live? I know you've monitored lots of these kinds of things in the private sector. How does it compare?

THOMPSON: It compares a lot worse. They had an artificial - they had a deadline. A company that had as many problems like this, (a) would probably better identify that they had a clear product management. They wouldn't have as complicated a system because they wouldn't have you're built in and such a crazy, complex way. And they would have seen the problems and then they would have stopped. They would have had better project managers reporting more to the CEO. And I think they would have aborted the mission.

KEENE: The Washington Post, and I believe it was this week, and I'll give them credit, had fabulous charts showing the state-by-state variance as we dive into this new form of health care. Who's winning the battle now? From where you sit, is there one state that stands out of getting it right?

THOMPSON: Okay, Kentucky and California.

KEENE: Kentucky was at the top of the fancy chart.

THOMPSON: It's interesting, right, because -

KEENE: What are they doing in Kentucky?

THOMPSON: They've built - what's so interesting that there's a huge divide in how the health care law will be, will work in Republican states versus Democratic states, Republican states which have denied some of the goodies, Democratic states which have taken them. So in the long run that will be the big split, but in the beginning it's just the states that have set up the system, right? California you're not surprised. Of course their people there really focused on the technical aspects of health care.

KEENE: Right.

THOMPSON: Kentucky the system is based there. There was probably a lot more attention put on to it and they probably had good managers.

KEENE: And are they making an activist effort to get the people that don't want to do this to do it, the healthy young kids? Is that the distinction?

THOMPSON: I think right now it's more of a technical and then it's - it's a technical distinction and then it will also become a cultural distinction once - I think what's going to happen with this health care law is once the system works, once people start doing it, you'll see it really spreading in states where it takes off because people will get the quotes. And they'll say, hey, this is good. They'll tell their friends.

KEENE: When is that? When is that on my calendar?

ALESCI: Tom.

KEENE: Is it like March?

FU: Next year.

KEENE: Is it the third week of December? Is it 2016? What's the when?

THOMPSON: It's a year from now.

ALESCI: You brought up a great point about young people -

KEENE: Then what's the incentive.

ALESCI: - and the fact that the real problem beyond the technical issues may be the fact that young people are not going to sign up in the necessary numbers to make this thing work. And my question is what -

THOMPSON: They'll possibly have the patience.

ALESCI: Yes. We're not going to definitely add a (inaudible).

FU: We've talked to [Amazon] and it's not [right coupon].

THOMPSON: Right, yes.

ALESCI: And the question is basically between and new premiums, possibly low youth unemployment and the fact that youths are having to repay larger and larger college bills, how much more of a strain is this on the youth of this country?

THOMPSON: Well it depends, right? If you consider it a strain because you have to pay monthly premiums, yes it's a strain. First of all, up to 26 you can stay on your parents' bill, so a lot of young people can do that. Secondly, it is going to save them a whole lot of money. If they don't get health insurance, and they have a big problem and they see their friends, and they get crushed and they realize, oh wait, there's actually this fairly cheap alternative, so it's not necessarily harmful for them. So all those trends might affect the other side of the equation.

FU: Well we'll see if these younger, healthy people sign up en masse before November 30th.

THOMPSON: I know. And if they don't there's trouble, or -

FU: Nick Thompson, Bloomberg Contributing Editor.

THOMPSON: Before December 31st. They have to - they and again and start working November 30th and sign up in the next month. We'll see.

KEENE: Very good.

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

urn:contentItem:59XF-5021-JB20-G3BT-00000-00Nicholas Thompson, Robert Profusek2013-11-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:25ZLexisNexisBLOOMBERG SURVEILLANCE7:00 AM ESTRobert ProfusekNEWSDomestic112697cb.556Nicholas Thompson, Robert ProfusekTom Keene, Cristina Alesci, Scarlet Fu, Nicholas Thompson

Robert Profusek, global head of mergers and acquisitions at Jones Day, is interviewed on Bloomberg SUrveillance regarding the stock market

NICHOLAS THOMPSON, BLOOMBERG CONTRIBUTING EDITOR, & ROBERT PROFUSEK, GLOBAL HEAD OF MERGERS AND ACQUISITIONS, JONES DAY, ARE INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG SURVEILLANCE

NOVEMBER 26, 2013

SPEAKERS: ROBERT PROFUSEK, GLOBAL HEAD OF MERGERS AND ACQUISITIONS, JONES DAY

NICHOLAS THOMPSON, BLOOMBERG CONTRIBUTING EDITOR

TOM KEENE, BLOOMBERG NEWS

CRISTINA ALESCI, BLOOMBERG NEWS

SCARLET FU, BLOOMBERG NEWS

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

TOM KEENE, BLOOMBERG NEWS: Robert Profusek is Global Head of Mergers and Acquisitions. He is a partner at Jones Day, a global law firm. And they represent 502 of the Fortune 500. Nick Thompson is Bloomberg Contributing Editor and with The New Yorker Magazine as well. Nick, what have you learned about Iran? I think The New Yorker has done great work on this, but what is distinctive that we need to know since our Saturday evening?

NICHOLAS THOMPSON, BLOOMBERG CONTRIBUTING EDITOR: The most distinctive thing to know is that we actually finally have a deal that we have diplomacy that seems to be working because sanctions were so effective. We're seen that putting strong pressure and then having negotiations, as we saw in Syria, now as we see in Iran, turns out to be a good mix. The American political system right now may actually be a very good political system for making deals because you have a president who wants to negotiate, and you have a Congress and you also have a history that indicates a willingness to go to war.

KEENE: Bob Profusek, we're going to talk about China here in a bit on M&A, but let's talk about the basic idea of 2013. What happened? Do we blame the lawyers that there were no deals?

ROBERT PROFUSEK, GLOBAL HEAD OF MERGERS AND ACQUISITIONS, JONES DAY: Well it depends on how you look at it. There were plenty of deals, not that many big mega deals, but some. There you mentioned -

KEENE: You guys are busy.

PROFUSEK: Yes. It's been a very good year.

KEENE: Your associates are fed. They're well fed.

PROFUSEK: And they are working on Thanksgiving.

CRISTINA ALESCI, BLOOMBERG NEWS: Well the lawyers are always busy.

PROFUSEK: Well -

KEENE: Do you know major -

ALESCI: The lawyers are always busy. The lawyers are doing the work and [they said] the bankers are the ones that want more, more, more, more.

KEENE: I totally agree with you. Major law firms have like eight Christmas parties.

ALESCI: Yes.

KEENE: That's what I know.

SCARLET FU, BLOOMBERG NEWS: Has that changed since -

ALESCI: Why? Did you crash all of them?

KEENE: It's just the way it is. But you guys have been busy, right?

PROFUSEK: Yes. We've been busy because it's been - there have been some big deals. There were Verizon we worked on.

FU: A lot in the telecom.

PROFUSEK: And Tokyo Electron. We're doing plenty of them, but they've been smaller. They've been sort of beneath the front page headlines size.

KEENE: Well we've got a lot to talk about this hour, particularly on China. This is an emotional issue as well.

(BREAK)

KEENE: Let's bring in Robert Profusek from Jones Day. Leadership is about a path, isn't it? This is one of the toughest things for companies to do.

PROFUSEK: Sure, and -

KEENE: Set up a leadership path.

PROFUSEK: And it can - and it's very difficult. And sometimes there's some breakage, as it was mentioned that when you set up an internal system there are winners and losers.

KEENE: Is there a best practice here that you see each and every day for corporations?

PROFUSEK: There's no question that the best practice is to hire from within. You know what you're getting when you go through external search.

ALESCI: Hire from within even though they've got to do better on the line and -

PROFUSEK: Yes. They've got to do better.

ALESCI: - decided basically very little experience on that front.

PROFUSEK: Yes. And that's an important point. When you got to make a shift in direction maybe there's a good argument for getting somebody from the outside, but the search process is inherently to some degree superficial. And I'm on a lot of, a couple of boards. You have a two hour -

FU: It's to make sure that you don't miss anything.

PROFUSEK: Yes. You have a two-hour interview. You do all the checking. Everybody says they're great.

KEENE: Are you representing Microsoft at this time? I just want to be -

PROFUSEK: No.

KEENE: Okay. You're not representing Microsoft. There's the ultimate search going on right now. You say you need an internal candidate, but that I suggest would be a different story with Alan Mulally front and center.

PROFUSEK: Well when you've got to make - when you need to make a strategic move that argues, as was just mentioned for maybe taking somebody with a different perspective. I'm not sure Walmart needs to make some sort of U- turn or even veer off the [front].

KEENE: I agree you're going to do.

ALESCI: Well one major question is the fact that McMillon has actually got a lot of international experience or some international experience. So that's raised some questions about whether or not there's going to be more of a focus given the fact that they really fumbled the ball on that front.

FU: Well there is some talk that perhaps he will focus more and internationally. David Strasser of Janney Montgomery Scott says he doesn't believe that he'll ignore the United States because the U.S. has actually quite well under Bill Simon. Actually David Strasser says that the biggest benefit that McMillon brings with him, his best strength, is that he's a great communicator. And that's important because this is a company with 2.2 million employees.

KEENE: It's unreal how big it is.

FU: They do business with so many vendors, with so many countries. And of course the investment community that is the Walmart CEO's job to speak to its different constituents.

KEENE: Let me bring in Michael Eckstein's quote from Credit Suisse. I spoke to him yesterday. They're terrific analysts on big box retail. Of course they go into that crucial season. We view McMillon as pragmatic and realistic. We think he will continue the legacy of focus on compliance and the core values of the company. And the idea is just simply passing the torch.

And here's more on it. We do believe that he will continue to hold the international division to very standards.

FU: He also suggested there might be possible divestitures from Walmart as well, which a lot of people have called for as a way to further unlock shareholder value as the parlance of the time.

ALESCI: More deals, more deals.

FU: More deals for Bob Profusek.

KEENE: It's going to be fascinating, just fascinating to see what Walmart does here. Again I go back to share price and that Mr. Duke delivered the goods, whatever the case with nominal GDP and domestic challenges.

ALESCI: He did, so certainly played a [credit] for that.

FU: Yes. So Bill Simon did do quite a bit. And Mike Duke also people are saying there's a lot of question marks over whether he was pushed out. No. The guy was getting ready to retire. Sure he had the shortest tenure of any Walmart CEO, but he did do more than just hold the ship together. He did get Walmart through a very tough period going through the financial crisis and recovery.

KEENE: Right, Nick Thompson with us as well from The New Yorker. You have written definitely on your grandfather, Paul Nitze, and the game theory if you will of war. What can leadership in corporations learn from your foreign affairs world? What can they learn from the complexity of diplomacy?

THOMPSON: Well the complexity of diplomacy is quite different from corporations because you're switching out the players every four years. And so you have a very limited time frame in which you have to negotiate. So some of the ways are different, but I think you do - you do have to very much plan for worst case scenarios. I think that's actually one thing that you can learn when you're planning an internal succession versus external succession. If you bring in from somebody from the outside you're entering a more high-risk environment than if you bring internally.

KEENE: And that learning curve, which is - anybody from the outside has a massive learning curve.

THOMPSON: Massive learning curve, which you actually see in politics where people come in and they tend to make a whole lot of mistakes in the beginning as they try to figure out how things -

KEENE: Is the president still in the learning curve? I got make some news here this morning. Help me, Nick.

THOMPSON: It's funny. The president, he came in and everybody said he has no experience and it's going to be very hard. And then he was very successful, at least legislatively the first couple years. Now that he certainly knows how to be president, there's not an experience question, he's had a really rough time.

KEENE: It's been [rough].

THOMPSON: Throw that theory out the window.

06:17:03

(BREAK)

06:23:41

KEENE: Robert Profusek with us with Jones Day. Bob, you look at the new activism. Bill Ackman was in our offices supporting a charity yesterday with our Erik Schatzker. Is Bill Ackman good for the market?

PROFUSEK: Well it depends on what length of period here, Tom, you're looking at. Part of activism is just is to accelerate the future to the present.

KEENE: And it's always been there.

PROFUSEK: And it's always been there. We called them back in the '80s before you were probably out of high school we called them raiders. It was a different word, but activism has been there. What's different about today is there's a huge amount of capital committed to it. If you're a CalPERS, some nice fund, -

FU: Yes. The fund simply management (inaudible).

PROFUSEK: - you've got to -

ALESCI: But this isn't just about corporate raiders or -

PROFUSEK: No.

ALESCI: - what you would call corporate raiders. This is long-term investors that are pressing for change. These are people who have nothing to do with the corporate raiders. They're actually supporting the Bill Ackman's and the Icahn's of the world behind the scenes. And here's the money that you actually (inaudible).

PROFUSEK: Well what they're - what they're saying is go back to whether it's good for employees then. What that means is cut back on your R&D now, but this is a message in Wall Street generally, which is I need more cash right now because I'm in this lower yield environment, don't want to invest. Don't do R&D. Don't buy that little thing. Give me the money.

KEENE: I critically look at the time frame of the activist. Who is supporting them besides themselves? It's almost a narcissistic event. Who's supporting them?

PROFUSEK: Well there's plenty of support in the institutional investor community. There's - it's with the shift in the corporate governance paradigm in general. You've got something called the ISS. We've got all these other forces. They're all for value today.

KEENE: Bob Profusek with us with Jones Day.

(BREAK)

KEENE: Bob, it's front and center here. There was a [Unical] blowup a couple years ago back and forth with Canada and such. Is there a new-new as we go into 2014 with Chinese acquisition of our assets?

PROFUSEK: Yes. I think it's - Smithfield was important psychologically. For a little bit everybody said, okay, maybe this is a national security issues, something called Cfius is the way it operates down in Washington, but Smithfield made sausage, and bacon and stuff like that. And it was sort of hard to argue it was a national security item, but it was big. It was $2.8 billion. And that was a little bit of a breakthrough, especially in the mind of the Chinese businessperson, saying that we can do this stuff.

KEENE: Is the distinction here a majority ownership, or are they more shrewd to take modest minority ownerships across a broad swath of companies, almost like a sovereign wealth fund?

PROFUSEK: Oh they're doing a lot of that.

KEENE: Yes.

PROFUSEK: When the - as of September 30 they had the [poor] side there was $12 billion of investment from China into the U.S. this year. That's way understated because what it doesn't include is things like investments in private equity firms, investments in deals that private equity firms put together that are ten - they take a ten percent position.

ALESCI: What?

KEENE: Are they visible under five percent? If they buy three percent of IBM or Walmart, do people -

PROFUSEK: No, no, not if it's a passive investment.

KEENE: It's invisible.

PROFUSEK: Yes, totally invisible.

KEENE: Yes.

PROFUSEK: And I would suggest to you that $12 billion number, which still is really big that five years ago it was $300 million, something like that.

ALESCI: What's the biggest challenge to actually getting a deal done because we know that the government would rather see the investment stay in the country and not export the capital to the U.S.

PROFUSEK: Actually the Chinese are trying to export their capital to the U.S. One of the things, law firms like mine we rushed over to China, and I think most professional services firms on the assumption that capital was going to China. That was totally wrong. It's coming.

KEENE: What have you learned in the last 24 months with Jones Day's work in China? What is the message you would have to Americans about business practices that you see in China?

PROFUSEK: It's well capital is coming the other way, and you've got to do your homework. You can't just come here and say we like to do this. You've got to - it's got to do prep work. The Smithfield deal was not prewired. You can't do that in this country.

FU: No.

PROFUSEK: But it was preplanned, pre thought out, both IR, government relations, everything else. And you can get it done. Now if you're - if a Chinese company is trying to buy a big tech company it gets all different. A year ago, -

FU: Yes.

PROFUSEK: - I don't know if you remember this Hawker Beechcraft, this situation made - they made airplanes. Now they're for commercial application, but what's the difference?

FU: They were more a national security concern.

PROFUSEK: Right, right, so of course.

FU: But the Chinese companies have gotten a lot more adept in navigating the political and regulatory waters.

PROFUSEK: Yes, absolutely.

FU: My question to you -

PROFUSEK: But the one thing that still is a little difficult in China is that the U.S. is a cacophonous place. And when Senator Schumer says, I don't like this, the Chinese businessperson says, wait a minute, and doesn't realize that that's just the way it is here that where we talk. In China if somebody like him said something it would over.

FU: Different, and different environment certainly. What's different between Chinese companies coming in and buying U.S. companies versus what Japanese companies did in the late '80s?

PROFUSEK: I - and from my point of view there is no difference really. Now there's more state -

FU: So it's all going to end in tears.

PROFUSEK: There's more state - I don't think so. There's more state money. And well one thing is don't forget China is sitting on a ton of treasuries. Would you rather be in treasuries or start putting and some of it -

KEENE: Okay. I'll go with that incentive, but I think the core issue of our viewers and listeners across America is who is investing in Smithfield? Is it a direct conduit from Beijing and the federal government? Or is it actually a freestanding company in China?

PROFUSEK: It's - oh no, freestanding yes.

KEENE: You buy the idea it's a freestanding company.

PROFUSEK: And it's a freestanding company, but let's not kid ourselves. It's a controlled economy. Someone has to say that's an okay thing to do.

KEENE: You don't think Beijing is rubberstamping some freestanding company's purchase of a pork maker and a sausage maker in America?

PROFUSEK: I think they're looking at it before it's done. State-owned companies are state-owned companies.

KEENE: Okay, interesting.

PROFUSEK: The state has a role.

FU: Well, Bob Profusek -

KEENE: Bob Profusek, fascinating, fascinating.

FU: Yes. Stay with us. We're going to have more on this, but we want to also pivot to another topic here. Elon Musk's SpaceX postponed the scheduled launch of its Falcon 9 spacecraft last night. The rocket was less than four minutes from liftoff at Cape Canaveral when the countdown was halted. Musk says there was a problem with the Falcon's liquid oxygen tank. The launch has been rescheduled for Thursday.

A little more than a year ago SpaceX completed the first regular cargo mission in commercial space flight. This mission will carry a communications satellite into orbit. So SpaceX couldn't get it done, and all this talk about how private companies are in a better position than the government to move forward.

KEENE: Right. Nick Thompson, Elon Musk has been a huge 2013 story. You've covered this. You've pondered it. You looked at it. What's your report card on Mr. Musk?

THOMPSON: And this is actually this stutter in the launch is sort of indicative of his year. He's an extraordinary year of success after success, but every time there's a string of success there's some setback. There's a fire at a Tesla factory. There's something that goes wrong with Tesla. There's something that goes wrong with SpaceX, but basically he's had the most interesting, most successful year (inaudible).

KEENE: It's amazing to see. And I've been a critic at times in writing for Bloomberg Businessweek, but the fact is this guy has jumpstarted innovation. He seems to be impervious to criticism.

THOMPSON: He's impervious to criticism. He's jumpstarting innovation. And he hasn't stopped dreaming big. He's going to build us a hyper loop that gets us to travel across (inaudible).

KEENE: Well that's what he says he's going to do, but what do you - what would you -

THOMPSON: Would you believe that of anybody else? No. You'd laugh it out of the room.

KEENE: What is your - what - that's true. What is your prescription for 2014 for Elon Musk?

THOMPSON: For Elon Musk he's probably going to start - we'll find (a) Tesla. Ideally for him Tesla will actually really start to make more inroads. We'll have a string of success, buy more and more cars and better and better. SpaceX will continue.

ALESCI: Do you think that it will grow into its tough Tesla specifically grow into its valuation, because we've seen the stock come up quite a bit.

THOMPSON: I'm not sure if it can grow into its valuation. I was just saying it should grow massively, not grow into its valuation. Let's not talk crazy here.

ALESCI: So you think it's overpriced then.

THOMPSON: Well Tesla there's a lot of promise. There are a lot of dreams built into Tesla, but there's also been a lot of success at Tesla. I think we'll see with Elon Musk the question is whether he'll get Ford to buy his current companies and he'll end up starting a fourth or fifth, and eventually whether those deals start to have an effect on them.

KEENE: Well Nick Thompson with us from The New Yorker, some interesting perspect - I'm fascinated by the year Mr. Musk has had.

FU: Yes. He's on the covers of all these different magazines. I'm seeing him left and right.

ALESCI: He's just like an interesting guy, right? He's a - he has the greatest ideas.

KEENE: What's the Dos Equis, he's had the world's most -

ALESCI: Most interesting man. I don't know if you can use him for that.

THOMPSON: So weird, and there are so many bizarre things about him, right? He's a man who has lots of children because he wants to improve the overall intelligence of the human race he said. He's a quirky guy.

FU: Yes.

KEENE: And I did that theory.

THOMPSON: That's all so good.

ALESCI: But that's part of his whole -

FU: For the new era.

ALESCI: Like that's just part of his whole character. It's the one that he's put out in public.

THOMPSON: Yes. And it seems genuine and real.

06:38:00

(BREAK)

06:43:16

KEENE: Nicholas Thompson with us with The New Yorker and Bloomberg adviser as well. Nick, this speaks so much of that phrase Eurosclerosis. We clear markets. We go back to Friedrich Hayek, 1945.

THOMPSON: Right.

KEENE: We do it. We clear markets. It's ugly, but we do it and they don't. Do you see any hope that Europe can become more malleable, more supple?

THOMPSON: You would actually you would hope so, but and there are so many cultural differences. There are language differences. They've tried to break us down. We've a pretty sclerotic political system right now that makes it hard to act. You saw that in our response to what happened in 2008. We responded very slowly, responded inefficiently, but we did actually respond. And that's a large reason why that chart heads up in the top.

KEENE: Yes.

THOMPSON: Europe has a much, much, much tougher time, but it's also the different kinds of responses. We chose more of a stimulus. They chose more of an austerity. A lot of people would make the argument that that's part of what's causing this [crisis].

KEENE: Yes. It's a huge question I think for next year, can Europe really get their act together now that the crisis is over.

(BREAK)

ALESCI: But I'm curious to get our guest host's opinion on this, Bob Profusek from Jones Day. What do you think went wrong or right at Sony in terms of the way Dan Loeb handled it?

PROFUSEK: Well I'd say Dan Loeb handled it about the best you can with a company like Sony. There was no question that he wasn't going to push around the company. This isn't some U.S. company where the boards are going to get weak kneed. And they didn't do what he said, which is separate the entertainment business, but the company's doing something, talking about it just right now that maybe -

ALESCI: Do you think the company would have done something if it were not for Loeb in there agitating?

PROFUSEK: And that's the question. And I guess my guess would be not really.

ALESCI: So in this case maybe an activist was basically -

PROFUSEK: Yes. And Japan's different. Companies are different. They're - there's the interlocking ownership and it's not like it is here where it's, again cacophony in the marketplace.

FU: Well we'll continue to monitor this one because it will play out certainly in the next couple of months. We want to switch topics here because the president's deadline of November 30th is to fix the healthcare.gov website is fast approaching. There are also fresh doubts over whether the site, which has been dogged by glitches will be fully functional by then. Can the Obama Administration take another hit from this beleaguered rollout?

And joining us now is our guest host for the hour, Bloomberg Contributing Editor Nick Thompson. So, Nick, November 30th is supposed to be the deadline, but Kathleen Sebelius, the Secretary of Health and Human and Services, has managed expectations lower, saying it's still going to be a work in progress beyond this date. And now the White House says - said that the website will work for the vast majority of users by the state. The problem seems to be the White House doesn't understand process is product. This process is what people are going to remember.

THOMPSON: Yes. And that is absolutely true, but I do think they're making the right move. Clearly even if they fixed everything they've identified by November 30th there are still going to be lots of terrible things that happen because of the press that's come beforehand. There's going to be lots of negative press on everything that happens, every idea that gets hacked or something like that. So they do absolutely have to manage expectations. I think they've done a pretty good job of saying it's not going to work perfectly. It's scheduled for a Saturday so there won't be too much attention. And it - they actually in the last 48 hours have started sounding a lot more optimistic than before.

FU: Okay.

THOMPSON: So maybe there's something we don't know.

FU: Maybe, maybe. We'll see how that goes, but how does this compare with say the live, a performance of an e-commerce website that goes live? I know you've monitored lots of these kinds of things in the private sector. How does it compare?

THOMPSON: It compares a lot worse. They had an artificial - they had a deadline. A company that had as many problems like this, (a) would probably better identify that they had a clear product management. They wouldn't have as complicated a system because they wouldn't have you're built in and such a crazy, complex way. And they would have seen the problems and then they would have stopped. They would have had better project managers reporting more to the CEO. And I think they would have aborted the mission.

KEENE: The Washington Post, and I believe it was this week, and I'll give them credit, had fabulous charts showing the state-by-state variance as we dive into this new form of health care. Who's winning the battle now? From where you sit, is there one state that stands out of getting it right?

THOMPSON: Okay, Kentucky and California.

KEENE: Kentucky was at the top of the fancy chart.

THOMPSON: It's interesting, right, because -

KEENE: What are they doing in Kentucky?

THOMPSON: They've built - what's so interesting that there's a huge divide in how the health care law will be, will work in Republican states versus Democratic states, Republican states which have denied some of the goodies, Democratic states which have taken them. So in the long run that will be the big split, but in the beginning it's just the states that have set up the system, right? California you're not surprised. Of course their people there really focused on the technical aspects of health care.

KEENE: Right.

THOMPSON: Kentucky the system is based there. There was probably a lot more attention put on to it and they probably had good managers.

KEENE: And are they making an activist effort to get the people that don't want to do this to do it, the healthy young kids? Is that the distinction?

THOMPSON: I think right now it's more of a technical and then it's - it's a technical distinction and then it will also become a cultural distinction once - I think what's going to happen with this health care law is once the system works, once people start doing it, you'll see it really spreading in states where it takes off because people will get the quotes. And they'll say, hey, this is good. They'll tell their friends.

KEENE: When is that? When is that on my calendar?

ALESCI: Tom.

KEENE: Is it like March?

FU: Next year.

KEENE: Is it the third week of December? Is it 2016? What's the when?

THOMPSON: It's a year from now.

ALESCI: You brought up a great point about young people -

KEENE: Then what's the incentive.

ALESCI: - and the fact that the real problem beyond the technical issues may be the fact that young people are not going to sign up in the necessary numbers to make this thing work. And my question is what -

THOMPSON: They'll possibly have the patience.

ALESCI: Yes. We're not going to definitely add a (inaudible).

FU: We've talked to [Amazon] and it's not [right coupon].

THOMPSON: Right, yes.

ALESCI: And the question is basically between and new premiums, possibly low youth unemployment and the fact that youths are having to repay larger and larger college bills, how much more of a strain is this on the youth of this country?

THOMPSON: Well it depends, right? If you consider it a strain because you have to pay monthly premiums, yes it's a strain. First of all, up to 26 you can stay on your parents' bill, so a lot of young people can do that. Secondly, it is going to save them a whole lot of money. If they don't get health insurance, and they have a big problem and they see their friends, and they get crushed and they realize, oh wait, there's actually this fairly cheap alternative, so it's not necessarily harmful for them. So all those trends might affect the other side of the equation.

FU: Well we'll see if these younger, healthy people sign up en masse before November 30th.

THOMPSON: I know. And if they don't there's trouble, or -

FU: Nick Thompson, Bloomberg Contributing Editor.

THOMPSON: Before December 31st. They have to - they and again and start working November 30th and sign up in the next month. We'll see.

KEENE: Very good.

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***
